If you're at the point of reading reviews to try to decide whether or not to buy this game, I'm assuming you find yourself in the same dilemma I found myself in: Should I buy Descenders or Rider's Republic? I wanted a downhill biking game and it was such a hard decision. Well, luckily I own both, so I can compare them side by side so you don't have to. I'll just copy+paste my review on both so you can compare the two without purchasing both. (Or, heck, DO buy them both. They're both EXCELLENT games in their own regard, with each of them having unique things that make them 'stand out' from the other.)

So without further ado, Descenders vs Rider's Republic.

Q. Which one 'feels' more like biking? Which feels more natural?
A. Hands down, Descenders. I don't know what it is, but I've never played a biking game where the riding just felt absolutely natural and 'right.' Don't get me wrong, the riding in RR is still great, but there's something about the flow of D that makes it feel like you're actually riding a bike. (Also, RR, despite being loads of fun, can feel a little glitchy at times.. and occasionally, if my Steam Deck lags a little, my rider will come to a dead stop in a heartbeat... which is somewhat problematic in a game all about maintaining high speeds.) In D you will feel the trails, feel the speed, feel the jumps. It feels right.

Q. Which has more to do in the game?
A. Hands down RR. I'll speak a little more about D in a bit, but let's be real here: RR has bikes, skis/snowboards, wing-suits and more (and skating if you buy the DLC's). There are all kinds of side quests in RR, different types of races, all kinds of goals and achievements... It is an open-world setting, and that world is filled with things to do. In contrast, while the levels in Descenders are large, the only kind of 'open world,' so to speak, are the lobbies and the multiplayer arenas (where you can't gain Rep).

That's not to say there's nothing to do in D. You can mess around in the lobby with other players, you can go on adventurous rides, conquer boss jumps, and pull off great stunts. You can go play in the multiplayer worlds. There's plenty to do - it's just not filled to the brim with content like RR.

However - it needs to be said that sometimes quality vs quantity is a thing. Maybe more on that next.

Q. Which has more VARIETY?
A. That's right - although RR has a TON of stuff to do, it HAS to be pointed out that Descenders' levels are procedurally-generated, so each time you go on a ride your paths will be different. Now, it's not so different that you'll feel like you're in a different world every time.. but the paths ARE different enough that it will absolutely keep you on your toes. You can't attempt to 'memorize' the paths like you can with RR. You'll ABSOLUTELY have to establish some real flow in D.

Q. Which has better graphics?
A. This one is VERY hard. While RR is an enormous game filled to the brim with details, there's something extremely beautiful about D as well. Both of them have highly detailed worlds, and each one has their own 'feel' to them. Descenders makes you feel like you're in this lonely, far-away natural world, while Rider's Republic makes you feel like you've gone on vacation to a huge park of sorts filled to the brim with people. The 'world' seems to flow a little more naturally in D, while the cuts between biomes in RR can sometimes feel a little abrupt. I don't know if there's a clear winner on graphics - despite RR having way more assets, the simple beauty of D has its own stunning appeal. I think this one will just be a matter of opinion for each player.

Also has to be said that it can take a bit of a beast to run RR at full settings. My Steam Deck seems to be able to handle most graphics-intensive games fairly well, but I actually had to turn down the settings on RR just a little because I was losing FPS and it was getting glitchy.

Q. Which has more multi-player/better function?
A. Probably RR, although the multi-player in D still adds a lot of fun. In D you can ride around with others in the lobby, go to multiplayer worlds full of random stuff, and encounter other players out on the trails. Far as I'm aware, that's about it. Out on the trails you're not really racing others, but it's still cool to encounter them.

Meanwhile, in RR, there are 'mass races' with 50+ other players (although I'm pretty sure there are plenty of players who are able to cheat), you can challenge others, etc. So yes, there's a lot more competition in RR. It's also a little more seamless in RR - in D, players have a tendency to 'glitch' and fly all over the place. Both are fun, but if multi-player competition is extremely important to you, probably RR.

Q. Which has more 'stuff' to get?
A. No clue. I have LOADS AND LOADS of 'stuff' in D. Bikes, accessories, shirts, pants, helmets, it seems like there is just no end of customization stuff to get in D. Meanwhile, in RR, I have plenty of 'stuff' like bikes, skis, snowboards, wingsuits, and all kinds of garbage... but very little in the way of clothes and accessories. Crappily,  it seems that if you want clothes or things like that, you've got to actually purchase (like, with real money) in-game currency to spend. I have no desire to spend money on clothes. That stuff should be won by playing, just like in D. Seems greedy of RR. 

One difference is that in D, the different 'bikes' are mainly just skins, whereas the different gear in RR actually have their own performance stats. So this is again a matter of opinion - if you like things to be fair and be more about skill, you'd prefer D, where everyone's bikes are on a more equal playing field... if you want to have the 'fastest gear around,' then I guess RR.

But remember, again, there are TONS of things to be had in D, and a lot of stuff in RR that is locked behind a paywall. It will be up to you to decide how you want to play it.

Q. Better music/sounds?
A. No clear winner. I don't usually like in-game music so I often turn music in games off, but in both of these games I leave it on. The music in D gives you more of that 'I'm riding with determination in some far-off and lonely world,' while the music in RR tends to give more of that 'woo-hoo, I'm riding like crazy in this adrenaline-junky world filled with people.' Each on has their own appeal.

For the sound effects, I prefer the ones in D. Once again, they just feel more natural. (Despite being a somewhat smaller production, there's actually a lot about D that just feels more 'natural.')

Q. Which has a better 'reputation' system?
A. IDK. Each one has a 'reputation' system where you can show off your skill in the game... It's REP in D, and 'stars' in RR. I'll say that the rep of other players is a lot more visible in RR. You of course earn rep and stars by doing well in the game.

Q. Which one has more daily/seasonal events?
A. RR. D has a 'daily run' which can be a lot of fun, but I hear that a lot of folks are able to cheat and get billions of points or whatever. (But then again, from some of the races I've done on RR, I am almost certain there's cheating there as well.) Meanwhile, there are always a ton of on-going events in RR.

Q. Is there a clear winner between the two?
A. Not for me. I play both. When I feel like playing with a ton of variety or against other players, I'll switch over to RR. When I want an experience that feels just about as natural as it can get, I switch over to D. When I want to try to earn the fastest/best gear, I'll play RR... when I want to win an enormous variety of customization, I'll play D. When I want a more open world 'free play' style I'll play RR.. when I just want to go through procedurally generated series of levels I'll play D. I really do believe that each game has its own unique strengths and weaknesses.

Q. Worth full price?
A. Wait for a sale if you can. But for either one, they're both fantastic, so it wouldn't be the end of the world to buy at full price.

Every time I try to play for over half an hour or try to boot up the bmx introduction the screen goes black and then the game crashes. This is a problem I've had for a while with ubisoft games, when far cry 5 kept crashing I thought it might just be a glitch, when far cry 3 kept crashing I thought that it was a coincidence. But now that for the 3rd time I have bought and played an ubisoft game with the same problem I know something must be fixed. I am running of a completely competent GTX 1650 that can run, call of duty modern warfare, red dead redemption 2 and many other games that are way more gpu intensive than this. I will update this post when I upgrade to a 4060 to see if that fixs it.

Let me give you game designers a free bit of advice.

Aside from the D-pad (for movement), the pause button, and the menu button, game controllers have EIGHT buttons. It's a good idea for you geniuses to make games that only require the player to use, at most, EIGHT buttons.

Not doing so results in multiple functions being assigned to the same button on the controller. This means that the players' characters are going to be helplessly flopping around the screen, effectively making the game TOTALLY UNPLAYABLE.
-----------------
Uninstalled. Ubisoft will NEVER get another dime from me. This is just moronic planning on their part.

GOOD FUN GAME

- The chaos and mayhem of the mass races is a key selling feature of the game and they absolutely RULE!
- Game lets you try all of the year 1 pass toys like the rocket skis as well as the bmx bikes and skateboards for free in both some of the rotating weekly LIVE challenges, and some of those creators' custom events which is appreciated and helps players decide on what toys they wanna buy for the freeroam.
- Game will constantly populate the open world with short-life ghosts of players that make the world feel quite alive, it's quite the clever illusion and probably the first time I've seen a game try emulating world life of this scale, it's basically the next best thing you could ask for in an open world multiplayer game after, you know, the actual other players. (Which is especially awesome in my case if you read the last point in this review)
- The sense of progression with the account star system is fantastic, even if you login for 5 mins and grind some rails and that's it, you'll still get a star or 2. While mass races and weekly challenges are the best sources of stars, it's ultimately just an account playtime indicator which serves its purpose well. For reference, I've played for about 50 hours and my account has over 2000 stars. I've seen some flashy-looking dudes with hundreds of thousands of stars. Seasonal progression and rewards are also pretty neat with best-stat gear or exclusive seasonal cosmetics.
- Game is an absolute content creator's paradise! Between the ability to completely hide the HUD, the excellent photo mode and all of its settings, and more recently with the skateboard expansion, the replay mode? Capturing memorable moments here is super easy. All of the listed features are not new unique inventions by any stretch, but a lot of games choose to include them when they don't need to, or get how much flexibility to allow the player all wrong. This game has JUST the perfect amount of options without feeling too little or too many.
- Cosmetics and emotes are not too stingy if you don't spend and play those weekly challenges, but I would have preferred a bit more generosity on that front. It's kinda annoying that not only is the game NOT free, where the cosmetics only cash shop is an acceptable trade-off for monetization, but it's also not even cheap, and on top of that it still expects you to spend some cash if I want to get me some outfits with cloth physics or neon/animated shirts and masks? Pretty greedy from ubisoft if you ask me.
- I need a grappling hook/swinging mechanic, or short-range teleport. The game's greatest strength is its traversal and it's kind of criminal that I have all of these extreme sports available, but not a more unique/engaging way to encourage switching between them other than literally navigating terrain made for other sports. Perhaps that could be a great idea for a future expansion or 2 for the game.
- I also need a custom decal system that allows me to customize and paint our skateboards/snowboards/hoverboards/etc, or at least a gear transmog system that lets me copy the appearance of any of the unlocked skateboards/skis/rocketwings/etc to whatever I have equipped. The curse of choosing between good stats and good looks should long have been a thing of the past by this day and age of gaming, Ubisoft. Where it not for the good range of available cosmetics for your character, this would have been a MAJOR problem given that the game is all about YOUR STYLE, but thankfully this is just a minor personal inconvenience for me.
- I also don't understand why the game feels the need to be always online. There is a literal zen mode in the main menu which is basically solo mode. And this isn't a seriously competitive game where cheating is of any concern. Again, you will understand my frustration with this a little better if you read the last point in this review. I am basically always playing this game solo all the time anyway. This is a foundation that absolutely deserves immortalization in some form or another, it tries some wild ideas and it actually nails some of them quite well for some really fun times. I truly hope Ubisoft will include an offline patch that allows playing the game without internet at the end of the line.

- As a very chill game this is overall a little expensive, I would ultimately recommend buying either the skate or complete edition and ONLY when they're on sale. With that out of the way, this is the game I play in between my other big time-sinks and greatly enjoy the variety to this day. 
It doesn't NAIL any particular sport to the point of skating being more fun than a standalone skateboarding game, for example, or skiing/snowboarding being better than SSX/etc, (and I really hate the occasional jank of bike racing controls Ubisoft, please fix that shit asap), but it gets the core aspects of all of these sports right. And in the end, that's what truly matters as you fly/skate/glide/ski/bike across the chasms/mountains/canyons/forests/parks/snow. More content is planned for the next season including the new longboard and the custom event editor, so the game will continue to thrive for a time, I suspect.

- (Very specific and niche complaint which will likely not apply to you) Apparently, connecting to this game from Egypt causes ISP throttling problems which means I am not able enjoy any of the actual multiplayer aspects of the game (including the mass races), without using a VPN, and this sucks. Ubisoft doesn't give two shits about trying to change their servers' required ports for access so Egyptian buyers be warned on this one.

I got the Complete Edition at a 50% discount (which technically equals to full price for this game if y'ask me) and it's not a bad purchase honestly. Kinda complex for an onboarding experience, not to mention there are a lot of sports to figure out at the same time. I have grown to like a lot about this game, pros outweighing cons but lets talk about it:

Pros:
- Competes with dedicated indy games and gives them a run for their money, while being an all-in-one solution (looking at Skating, BMX and Snowboarding/skiing, Downhill games) 
- Cool open world exploration with jetpacks, wingsuit, paragliders etc. Not to mention you can bike, skii and skateboard around too, almost seamlessly switching sports on the fly.
- Lots of various terrain, plenty of decent tracks but honestly even just freestyling down a path can lead to plenty of replayability as it's almost never duplicatable.
- Music choice is excellent (Ugly Duckling, Black Thought, People Under The Stairs!) for a game trying to be the Fortnite of extreme sports this is as good as it gets.
- Day/Night cycle, you can pick your time as well from the map.
- Community is alive, compared to many of the extreme sports games it's great. Compared to the most popular games, it's on the lower side. Like 50-100+ people playing on my server at a time from what I've seen.
- Multiplayer features work well, rare lag when more than 20 people are in the middle of your player during a 60 man race.

Cons: 
- Customization is honestly not that great, despite the large amount of choices. You either like something or you don't, no color changes, no different looks (like Skate 3 where you can choose hat tilt, shirt tucks etc.. not even hoodie on/off toggle)
- There are only a few faces to choose from for either sex and they are all cheeks apart from 1. Hairstyles are also lacking, not to mention beanies cut out hair completely (to avoid awkward clipping obv but that should have been addressed differently)
- Requires the Ubi launcher which only works in Beta and you gotta hit cancel three times on the open prompt before it actually starts up. Not the hugest hassle but it's more of an assle. heh
- Requires online connection at all times (the offline mode doesn't work when their server is out)
- The gear itself is cosmetically locked (there's no transmorphing it either) so if you want the best performing gear, bike, board w/e you are stuck playing a single item or two for the rest of endgame. Not even griptape for the skateboards, wheel color, etc... LOCKED.
- Mod support is made near impossible (still zero mods to this day) due to Ubi making their code extra saucy and trying to make some extra money on the cooler looking (in their opinion) gear which is made only obtainable by real cash. 

P.S. I'm gonna need a LONGBOARD FUNKIE for the Skateboard career.

P.P.S. PETITION to add AGGRESSIVE INLINE make it into the game! Ubi you already have a rollerblading game besides that the rest of the trick animations can be reused from the ski stuff - i.e. super low barrier to entry and you have untapped profit potential here as there hasn't been a good inline game since the Aggressive Inline on the PS2!

Prada on the Slopes:

When I heard about Riders Republic teaming up with Prada, I knew I had to have it. Who wouldn't want to carve up mountains in the chicest gear possible? However, my journey into this open-world sports paradise wasn't all glitz and glamour, and it took a bit of time to find my stride.

As a die-hard fan of Steep, I went into Riders Republic with certain expectations. Unfortunately, my first attempts at skiing and snowboarding left me feeling like I was trying to dance in high heels for the first time – a bit awkward and definitely not runway-ready. The gameplay, especially for my beloved ski and snowboard activities, took some getting used to, and I found myself missing the familiar feel of Steep.

But fear not, because where Riders Republic truly shines is in its biking gameplay. The developers seemed to have put some serious thought into it, and biking through the expansive world felt nothing short of fantastic. The controls were intuitive, the terrain responsive, and I couldn't help but get a genuine adrenaline rush as I raced down slopes and took on daredevil jumps.

The disappointment with skiing and snowboarding was quickly forgotten as I found myself spending more and more time on two wheels, tearing through the landscape in style. It's like the virtual Prada gear was tailor-made for the biking experience, elevating my fashion-forward adventure to new heights – or should I say speeds?

While Riders Republic might not have entirely lived up to my expectations as a skiing and snowboarding enthusiast, the biking element saved the day, delivering an unexpectedly enjoyable experience. So, if you're ready to trade in your skis for a sleek bike and embrace the Prada-fied thrills, Riders Republic might just be the stylish escape you never knew you needed. Just be prepared to give those virtual slopes a bit of time before you hit your fashion stride!

I think this would be a really fun game if I could figure out how to unlock any of the multiplayer functions. I have no idea but I've been playing the game for... nine hours (on PC, because it's cross save and my dumb ass bought it on 2 platforms?) now and haven't been able to accomplish whatever it is I need to in order to unlock this function in the game. Oh, and I considered deleting my game save to start over in the hopes of identifying whatever secret task it is I need to accomplish to unlock the ability to like... play with other REAL people, and apparently short of creating a brand new Ubisoft account there's no way to delete your saves for this game.

The game starts with the abyssmal sin of the "unskippable cutscene that turns into 20s of playing before another unskippable scene" which is meant to be the bulk of the games tutorial. Once you finish that you'll get a few events on your map which takes forever as it want to highlight all of them one at a time (again unskippable) then when it finally finished showing me everything all but two of them dissapeared. Since I didn't want to do either of those I road the bike out of the starting area and just kept riding till a few of the previously shown events appeared back on the map.

The good side, the trick interface is a good improvment over steep. You feel more in control. The "trick assist mode" reasonably helps you land without feeling like its fighting you or like you don't have to try. The manual mode is excessively tricky to master but it should be, so that's fine.

The bad side, you are way more limited in what you can do in free roam or "zen" as compared to Steep. You can't just pick a spot, pick some equipment, and have fun. Plenty of equipment is locked to only in specific sports. This means ski-ing over to a snowboard event so you can ride a snowboard within the confines of that event.

If like me, you're just looking for a modern coolboarders to play, skip this entry. Because while the actual snowboard riding is fun, the getting to any of it is not.

A Ubisoft game that has avoided the ire of reviews on Steam must be doing something right.  Even their greatest games get trashed due to the launcher. (The launcher is still trash, but has improved somewhat.)  

I tried this game for a few hours on Ubi+ and decided to pull the trigger while it's on sale.  
Great arcade x-sports game overall.  

The skate dlc is great despite a learning curve. You may need to struggle rewiring your brain to the controls like I did, but once you do this game is every bit as fun as any other I've played over the years.  I started with T and C surf factory and Skate or Die.  Love THPS, Skate, Skater XL, and Session. This is a great arcade skate game. Gameplay is most similar to Skate, but with better animations.  Not quite as good as Skate in its depth and freedom of expression, but close.  Contrary to other reviews you CAN choose from different landing options; assisted, auto, and manual. If you are curious and hungry for an arcade skate game to play while EA finishes Skate 4, check out some gameplay on YouTube.  

I bought the game for the Skateboard dlc, but overall the gameplay is solid. 

I turn off the music and dialogue as I can't stand the sterile vibe of the focused-group-friendly sports game aesthetic.  Too many driving and extreme sports games have adopted this style and I really have a hard time believing anyone actually enjoys it.
Amazing game over all with good physics, and is a very well made and balanced game. very fun and would recommend to anyone.

It took 10 minutes to start getting solicited by the game I just bought to tell me half the features in the game cost more money. I was ushered to the BMX park to be told I have to pay more money for that section of the game. Then I go to check out the skateboarding and it says the same thing. 

The physics and gameplay are very boring, simplified versions of the many games they ripped off. It's trying to be Skate but with copy/paste execution that feels more like THPS. It's trying to be Descenders but with lazy, on-rails physics, automatic landings, and no carving. The snow sports are too forgiving to be enjoyable. You can pretty much slam and mash buttons all day without crashing. 

It would be nice if the servers worked but they have constant traffic issues that prevent people from even being able to buy these expensive features that should already be included in the game.

Overall, Ubisoft has truly outdone themselves. They hit new levels of incompetence with this one. Let alone, they're knowingly data-mining all of us when we play their games. Really despicable people at Ubisoft...

Would like to have a "meh" option.

Its a fun game for sure. The biggest problem with Riders Republic is in how it somehow downgraded in comparison to Steep. Sure you now have a lot of more sports that are not just snow-sports. But the controls feel subpar in direct comparison. This is especially bad for the snow-sport-disciplines as Steep was feeling much better. I dont quite understand, why they would downgrade from their already existing systems from the predecessor. But thats how it is.

The progression system is absolutely flawed, as you have actual loot that differs in its stats. You dont feel like achieving something, because most of the time the loot is just pure useless clutter which you will also never use in the future because of the loot quality differences. This also means you have to play the game for a solid 50 hours+ to actually have the best items and be able to compete on the leaderboards. Its not even guaranteed to get a good item just by playing the carreer, which means you might have to grind endless hours just to get a lucky drop in the lootbox system. This is beyond fucked up in my opinion.

In Steep there was only cosmetic changes, which was good, because it ultimately means the only thing holding you back was your own lack of skill. Riders Republic is completely different. You will never compete before investing into the game at least 50-80 hours. You could say its the longest tutorial a video game has ever done.


I cannot say anything bad about the price, because what you get for around 40$ is a lot. 
I can understand the pain when you buy everything without a discount tho. Because literally everything is hidden behind a paywall. Wanna Skateboard? Go buy it. Wanna ride the snow-mobile? Go buy it. Steep was not different in that regards, but the paywall was not as big.

The whole presentation is made for 10 year olds and feels like playing Forza Horizon. In comparison to steep this is bad as well. Its not so much about the vastness of the nature and about exploring good lines. It also lost a big chunk of realism. Sure, Steep wasnt a very realistic game, but Riders Republic is even more far away from that point. Prepare to do 999999 degree flips while landing on a rail after a 500m jump.


Why do I still recommend it? As I said, I would like a "meh" option. But there is no other extreme-sports game out there which even comes close to this game. It has a huge map, and the different activities are fun. There is a lot to like. This game shines in downhill biking and bmx. It feels like it was made for that.

But if you only buy this game to play a Steep successor - you will be disappointed. I have warned you.
If you only want a realistic snowboard game, buy Shredders. If you want a Skateboard Game, better wait for Skate 4. If you want a good ski-game, yeah no, I feel you.

Gameplay
The game hosts various challenges you can tackle in about a dozen designated event types, snowboarding and skiing, mountain biking, flying with rocket wing and wingsuit, the DLC skateboarder and BMX as well as the toys. A lot of fun and varied ways to traverse this beautifully made map. If you haven't guessed yet; freeroam is easily my favorite aspect of this game.

You can also participate in races called events against CPUs, winning these will get you exp for the relevant career. Leveling your career up will reward you either with better gear or bucks you can spend on outfits. These outfits are on weekly rotation. While tastes are subjective I think there's plenty of good outfits you can earn for free. You can also earn gear and outfits from completing sponsor challenges.

Beyond this there's a lot more activities you can participate in like online Mass Races and Trick Battles. There's also Daily Sponsor Challenges, Weekly Challenges and Weekly Shop Rotations making you almost never run out of reasons to play even after finishing the main game.

Downsides
The game opens up with a tutorial and cutscenes, you'll quickly notice this game is a little cringeworthy, but that only makes up a tiny percentage of your playtime. The dialogue in general is a little cringeworthy, but again it only makes up a small percentage of your total playtime. The music isn't really good in my opinion, different strokes for different folks I guess. You can disable the ingame music, still use the other sound effects while playing your own music in the background.

Events are in my opinion the weakest part of this game, because it's an open world game it has to confine you to the intended area and route somehow. Basically keeping you from taking shortcuts during races or earning trick points in unintended locations. Their less than elegant solution is to put checkpoints every 30 feet. If you miss a checkpoint during a race you can kiss your victory goodbye. While an alternative solution is hard to come by, at least make the checkpoints less frustrating to deal with, I've lost tons of races just because I missed and arbitrarily sized checkpoint.

There's also little incentive to try if you can't make it into the top 3 as 4th till 12th (last) get the same rewards. I know it's supposed to reflect medals in real life, but from a gameplay perspective it makes little sense not to just make it more incremental. However once you have your gear you can mostly avoid events in the bulk of your playtime.

Monetization
This is basically an MMO so it should be considered a live service game and should be treated as such. Premium outfits shouldn't be considered any more or less taboo in this than other live service games like ESO or Warframe. Doing so is kind of a double standard. This is a game that gets regular updates and DLC. The developers need to be paid to get us that content.

I preface this because the game seems to catch a lot of flack for selling outfits for real money exclusively, However compared to other monetization schemes Riders is arguably one of the healthiest ones. I'd argue it's a really good example of how monetization should be done.

They're confident enough you'll enjoy the DLC items, they let you playtest them for free so you can make an educated decision whether you want to buy them or not. There are no lootboxes or fomo items as about half the seasonal Premium outfits can be bought outside their featured week and there's no pay-to-win at all. Even the bought currency isn't purposefully inconvenient as the incremental amounts you can buy are usually exactly what you need for a set number of outfits.

I will start with the basics ..
Graphics - 7/10 , good , but not amazing .
Difficulty - 8/10 the game wants you to learn to be able to do lots of tricks and score more points ... It's pretty hard , but fun .
Gameplay - 5/10 I give it 5 , because the game makes you sometimes handle easily , but sometimes it starts bugging out and it becomes actually unplayable for a moment , but it's still Ok.
Story - 2/10 No actual story going on in the game , just some chick that teaches you the basics and a welcome story line that is around 5 mins . long , cool intro tho .
Overall - 6/10 It's a very fun game , difficult at times and sometimes frustrating and annoying things happen , but that's ok , considering that you can drive a bike uphill with 60 km/h and downhill around 100-110 km/h . And yes you can fly in the game which is the hardest sport in my opinion , the controls are very weird and pretty hard to adapt to ... Anyways it's a fun game and if you like hard games or just love sports , this game is for you :)

I had multiple paragraphs written about all the issues I have with Rider's Republic, why I have low expectations for AAA games in general and how this one in particular still managed to let me down, and so on.

But nobody wants to read another wall of text from an overtired idiot as he nitpicks a bunch of tiny annoyances and the industry at large. I'll stick to the big one. Well, the biggest big one.

The biggest issue with Rider's Republic is the camera and lack of camera adjustment. The first of the third-person cameras moves around a bit but spends most of its time too close and too low directly behind your character's back, making it difficult or impossible to see directly in front of you. The second one is thankfully zoomed out a bit, but it's even lower and off to the side so now it's hard to judge exactly where you're facing beyond having just a general idea. Some games do the second "off-to-the-side" camera angle pretty well but this isn't one of them. I'm sure it's great for low-speed flatland tricks on a skateboard but not for anything else. And as I mentioned earlier you can't adjust this. There are no options to adjust the distance or height of the cameras at all. Why not? That alone is enough for me to [i] STRONGLY [/i] recommend against picking up Rider's Republic, even on a good sale. If you're not convinced, a quick Google search can show you a wide range of camera complaints. I'm surprised it's not better reflected in the reviews here. Anyway, thanks for reading. Overtired idiot, out.

8/10

NO SPOILERS!
RECENT CRITERION:
I can confirm that Steam Deck support is well done and playable. My only issue is that I'd like to be able to play offline on Steam Deck which is not currently supported. I don't care if I don't progress in levels playing offline, but I'd like to have the option. I rarely ran into game breaking bugs like freezing or stutter. 

SOUNDTRACK:
9/10 Matches the theme of the game, but gets repetitive like all games. Just use your own music once you re over the OST.

GAME PLAY:
10/10 for this genre. The sheer number of toys you can use and the size of the map are insane. Then you have around 20-30+ missions for each "toy?" that add countless hours of progression. It's the perfect laid back Xtreme sport game that you can pick up whenever you're interested. I'd recommend increasing your trick difficulty so you have some challenge landing things rather than being assisted by the game.

CRITICISM:
Paywalls ofc. You have to pay for a few campaigns like BMX separately. You also have to buy skateboarding and/or the campaign for sb separately. The skateboard DLC feels like it pays homage to Skate 3, but since it's a small part of the game there are only a few skate parks right now. Some of the DLC toys are a ton of fun, but some of them are pretty uninteresting too. 

OVERALL:
If you're a fan of the genre then this is a must have. If you want a new skate game then this can quench your thirst temporarily. I know I'll be coming back to this game based on how fun the free roam is. It's got great graphics and atmosphere that bring me back to hit the slopes again and again.

This isn't a replacement for Skate or Steep. In-fact the Skateboarding part is behind a paywall, sort of a DLC but just for the Skateboard and it's campaign. And yes, there are a few DLC rides in this game but my recommendation for anyone purchasing will be to only buy the base game that too on a sale. Those DLC rides aren't worth it. Even the base game should not be at the price it is during the non-sale period. But if you purchase it do mind that it may get stale after a few hours. The trick is to play it for an hour or so to get used to the controls and then quit it for the day. Only pick it up the next day to really see if you are a fan of it's gameplay (keep the Steam's 2 hour policy in mind though). Anyways it isn't a bad game but refrain from paying the full price for it, only get it from a sale.

It's Steep but with more everything. 
The good:
- More locations: 
- snowy mountains, snowparks, forest bike trails, deserts, canyons

- More sports:
- Skis, Snowboards, Bikes, Wingsuits, "Jet" wingsuits, BMX and Skateboards and possibly more in the future 
- each mountain sport has 2 variants: race and tricks 
- BMX have park and off-road variant (idk about skateboards)
- "Toy" sports: snowmobile, powered paragliding, hoverboards, jet bike & skis

- Better "sport campaign" challenges:
- it's clear which challenge is for which sport
- race and trick challenges have bonus side objectives
- tournament events
- actual collectibles: points, vistas and secret rideable gear
- in-game editor returns but it's overhauled

- Actual online gamemodes with other players:
- 64 player races for utter chaos (seriously, the devs who made collisions between players in mass races are absolute madlads and deserve a raise)
- 6 vs 6 trick battle (teams not only compete for trick score but also territory)
- free for all score attack and races
- "live" challenges (campaign missions but with / against other players)

And it works on Steam Deck / Linux now!

The bad: price - I'm not even rating "Deck" (skateboards) dlc because it's too expensive for now
Really, the only gripe I have with this game is the dlc model. Every next dlc costs as much as base game with previous dlcs, so it feels like you have to re-buy everything, even if you only want to update.

Gameplay:
Riders Republic features a variety of extreme sports, including biking, skiing, snowboarding, wingsuit flying, and more. The seamless transition between these activities within a vast open-world map is a standout feature. The controls are intuitive, offering a satisfying learning curve for newcomers while providing depth for experienced players. The sheer scale of the map, featuring iconic American national parks, adds a layer of exploration that keeps the gameplay fresh.

The multiplayer aspect introduces a competitive and social element, allowing players to engage in races, challenges, and events with others. The dynamic weather system and day-night cycle further enhance the immersive gameplay experience.

Visuals:
Visually, Riders Republic is a stunning showcase of the capabilities of modern gaming technology. The diverse environments, ranging from the red rock canyons of Bryce Canyon to the snow-covered slopes of Mammoth Mountain, are breathtakingly rendered. The attention to detail, especially in character animations and equipment customization, contributes to a visually engaging experience.

The use of vibrant colors and realistic lighting effects adds to the overall visual appeal. Performance on current-generation consoles and high-end PCs is commendable, ensuring a smooth and visually impressive experience.

Socials:
One of the game's defining features is its emphasis on social interaction. The multiplayer mode seamlessly integrates with the open-world concept, allowing players to share the experience with friends or strangers. The mass races, where dozens of players compete simultaneously, create a sense of scale and community rarely seen in sports games.

The social hub, where players can gather, customize their characters, and access various challenges, adds a sense of camaraderie to the overall experience. The integration of social elements feels organic and enhances the overall enjoyment of the game.

Pros:

Diverse Extreme Sports: A wide array of sports ensures that players have a variety of activities to engage in.
Open-World Exploration: The expansive open-world map offers a sense of freedom and discovery.
Seamless Multiplayer Integration: Multiplayer features enhance the social aspect of the game, providing a dynamic and engaging experience.
Stunning Visuals: The game boasts impressive graphics, capturing the beauty of the diverse American landscapes.
Intuitive Controls: Whether you're a novice or an experienced player, the controls strike a balance that caters to both skill levels.

Cons:

Occasional Technical Glitches: Some players have reported occasional bugs and technical issues that can disrupt the gameplay experience.
Learning Curve for Newcomers: While the controls are generally intuitive, there might be a learning curve for those unfamiliar with extreme sports games.
Repetitive Challenges: Despite the variety, some players feel that certain challenges can become repetitive over time.
Conclusion:
Riders Republic successfully delivers on its promise of an adrenaline-fueled experience, combining extreme sports with a vast open-world setting. The seamless multiplayer integration and stunning visuals make it a standout title in the sports genre. While it's not without its minor flaws, the overall package is a triumph for fans of extreme sports and open-world gaming alike.

Ubisoft's artistry in crafting a virtual universe where gravity bows to adrenaline deserves a standing ovation. In the grand tapestry of gaming, "Riders Republic" is a resplendent thread that weaves sport and spectacle into a transcendent experience.

Everything you loved from Skate 3, Steep, SSX, etc, all in one game. Smooth and fun mechanics, like switching gear instantly. Never knew I needed a game where you could ride your BMX bike off a cliff, then instantly switch to a wingsuit, but now I just want every game to have that option. Super fun game to just sit back and play for hours

The game is a great sandbox for you to have fun in, with a wide range of possibilities. The proposal of the game is to give you the feeling that you're in a extreme sports "resort" where anything goes and you're part of this massive community of like minded people. There are lots of NPCs everywhere you go and you'll never feel alone in the map, there are also lots of players sprinkled throughout the map for you to have those organic interactions.

The gameplay can be really in-depth and takes a while for you to get the grasp of it completely, but after that it all makes sense, it reminded me of "Session" and "Skater XL" in those regards. Talking about skate, the last big update was the addition of the skate sport, I didn't buy the skate edition and can't personally recommend that you do it so now, if you wish to play a skate game, those I mentioned before are better options. The base game with the year 1 pass combo appealed to me, the base game already has a lot of content for you to chug through and with the year 1 pass you have access to the BMX and it's events, with some accompanying "toys" (whacky funny vehicles) that add lots of events on top of the base game.

After you tackle all of that, in a few months time, get the skate with discounted price for added hours of gameplay. That will be my strategy at least.

At the end of the day it's just a really fun and whacky sandbox for extreme sports lovers, and at that it really excels!
Amazing game to sit back, relax, and just play around with the different sports. 9/10

"Riders Republic" delivers an exhilarating open-world experience, seamlessly blending extreme sports in a vast and visually stunning environment. The game's diverse range of activities, from downhill biking to wing suiting, offers a thrilling and immersive adventure. The graphics are impressive, capturing the beauty of national parks, and the multiplayer element adds a dynamic social dimension. However, occasional technical glitches and a steep learning curve for certain sports might deter some players. Overall, "Riders Republic" is a thrilling ride for extreme sports enthusiasts, offering a unique and expansive playground to explore.

I first saw this game when a youtuber I watched played it about a year ago. He said it was the game of your childhood dreams, and boy was he right in all the right ways. I got this game not to long ago now, and besides a few rage moments here and there, the game is perfect in my eyes. The graphics are stunning, the movement feels real and smooth, and the tricks are satisfying to land. Overall, if you like doing anything from snowboarding, mountain biking, skating, skiing, or using a snow mobile, you'll love it even more when you can do all of that and more in this expansive world that Rider republic offers.

This is my second title from UbiSoft. My first was STEEP, I had that refunded because of swearing in the game.

I refunded this because of various issues...

1) Very slow at startup, especially on first launch

2) They display a dialog window telling the user that they are installing a program called BattleEye. You get no choices to not install this app. This program is a program that monitors your entire system and sees if you are using cheating mods. It will also collect lots of information about your account, system and game. This is a 3rd party "spyware" program that tracks everything you do while you are playing the RR game (I don't about when you're not playing the game). I have no intention on cheating because I only play single player mode, I do not do online multiplayer. So, I don't need this "spyware" running in the background of my PC. Plus, I don't think this a cool thing for UBiSoft to be doing.

3) There were issues in the Option screen that if I changed a setting the screen would turn white and freeze the game. I would have to end task the game.

4) I also had Black Screen issues when I took screenshots using the Print Screen button on my keyboard. Therefore I couldn't take screenshots for my own uses or posting cropped images on discord or where ever.

I spent 45 minutes trying to deal with the issues and only got to play 5 minutes until I had enough. These two programs are my only games from UBiSoft that I have tried... and both were bad....

NO THANKS.... I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND ANY GAME from UbiSoft

WHO WOULD HAVE THOUGHT!!! Ubisoft is one of the most shady money hungry companies there is.  Yes the game is fun at times. Yes i do recommend buying this ON SALE on PS5. PLEASE DONT BUY AT FULL PRICE. DO NOT BUY JUST FOR STEAMDECK.

This game takes all of the worst things from Steep and turns them up to 100

Aggressive micro-transactions and expensive DLCs, check
Confusing menu UI and intrusive tutorials, check
Horrendously difficult events that are unfair by design to keep you restarting over and over again, check

This game as it all, so unless you are desperate for your action sports fix or absolutely need it. Do not buy this game at 40$. Maybe spend 10$ at most or wait until it goes on sale for an absolute steal. And keep in mind, Riders Republic was not made with the action sports enthusiast in mind. It was made to profit off them and the brands in that space, you are just dollar signs, not players.

this game has the worst physics and dialog i have ever heard and seen in a game, when ever i do a freeride bike event i will randomly be thrown off my bike for no reason when doing jump or just going in a straight line, with some tricks the exact same joystick/trigger combo will randomly do one of 2 different tricks, there are also many times where the physics is extremely inconstant and will suddenly push me off to a random direction even when i do the exact same thing multiple times it will almost always do something different, there are also time where things happen like i suddenly cant steer (its not because i'm sliding) or rotation will suddenly stop midair for no reason which makes it feel liked my controller is disconnecting but i never have any problems like this in other games, the game is also very greedy by pulling you over to the skateboard DLC every time you open your map and there's nothing you can do about it, almost everything in the store costs real money and the most basic of DLC's costing as much as the game its self, when ever the servers are down (which is quite often) you cant play the actual game with progression like the events and sponsors, you can only do zen mode which you cant even get to when you open the game through steam because it gets locked along side the actual game, you have to go into ubisoft connect and launch the game through there, you also have no other option than to play through ubisoft connect and it automatically downloads it when you open the game for the first time, i meant to get the game over 2 years ago when it launched on xbox but it kept getting delayed and i eventually lost interest and never ended up buying the game till it came out on steam. Over all its a very fun game for the first 6 hours but past that point the problems like randomly being thrown of your bike for no reason making it almost impossible to do some objectives and just too frustrating and un-fun

I bought this game looking for the next edition of steep, this game is not that. Maybe I'm nostalgic but I believe steep had better controls and physics and that's that. (at least in regards to snowsports)

However, as a multi-sport game with a variety of things to do, it's really fun. I can see it being even more fun with a group of friends. I went straight out and bought the ultimate edition, not one to spend big on games but aside from the complaints about greed (£34.99 for a skateboarding dlc that doesn't even compare to skate 3 is a bit insane), the game serves it's purpose and I think I'll get my money's worth from it.

The main thing that caught me off guard was the controls, I tried to use the "Steep" preset which is nothing like steep at all and ended up settling for "Trickster". 

Once you understand how triggers correlate to your grabs + left stick being your tricks, and pre-loading an input before you jump, then after you jump with right stick to manage your rotations, I believe it's the best working option for all the activities. 

Some mechanics and animations can be a little bit janky and it is fairly arcadey, but it does what it does well and it's good fun.

Yes and no. 

Gated DLC is frustrating with micro-transactions galore, but the game itself is pretty fun. The addition of BMX and skateboarding are an absolute blast, but you have to open your wallet for them and the pricetag is steep. If I had to recommend solely on gameplay I would, but the DLC is going to turn people off for sure. 

The controls are sometimes infuriating as well in a lot of the downhill events. No matter what it is you are controlling be it mountain bike, skiing, or snowboarding, the responsiveness of turning feels incredibly tanky and that has always been annoying to me. It does take some getting used to.

A jack of all trades, master of none extreme sports game. Fun for chilling with, and there's a competitive side if you care about it. A fun game even despite all of Ubisoft's bs. Though, that being said, the bike controls leave a lot to be desired and will take getting used to, and each individual sport you can play with (BMX, Skating, etc) is all less detailed than something dedicated to it. If you want a fun sandbox for every kind of extreme sport you can think of, this is a good game for you. If you want something more detailed and fleshed out for, example, skateboarding, look to games like Skater XL or Session.

I like the game but I do not like the payment politics Ubisoft provides because it looks like a scam. I bought the Ultimate edition with 1 year pass which is supposed to give access to "exclusive additional content" and it cost as the "Complete edition". After some time Ubisoft just replaced "Ultimate edition" with "Complete edition" and you will not find the Ultimate edition in the store.

I mean it is unfair and after a half-year, Ubisoft can replace the current "Complete edition" with a new addon the "Full pack" or "Extra-complete pack" and ask you to pay extra money again.

So I think Ubisoft should give players who had the Ultimate edition the Skate Plus pack addon for free because they already paid extra money for the game and they were promised to give additional content.

While Steep was a great game (100% on it) I really waited for this game because I love DH IRL.
This game was a total disappointment. Its overly complicated UI makes you feel lost all the time. Finding stuff is nauseating and the whole freedom and joy of exploration that was the soul of Steep is lost here..
In steep there was constant urge to do better and trying again was motivating. Here you finish a race and be glad it's over. shut down the game and maybe return after you forget how painful it was.

Controlling is more clunky and less fluid. There are always some tiny obstacles that suddenly lock you into place not letting you go. The whole experience feels not fun at all.
And what I find the biggest failure of all: You unlock gear and get your favorite equipment but there's no point in using it because all equipment has stats so you're forced tyo use the "best" stats making the actual equipment irrelevant.

In Steep they were cosmetics so you could use any equipment and truly be "you". Here you are forced to use equipment some idiot chose to rank better stealing the decision from you. For example Burton Custom is ranked 803 pts while Nitro Santoku is 900 pts. IRL both are great boards but if you think Custom is Mikkel Bangs choice for Natural Selection Tour and Ben Ferguson has Custom os Hometown Hero no one rides Santoku. Jared Elston had Team Pro. Hailey Langland had Karma. Yet someone decided Santoku is better board here and if you want to use Custom you're putting yourself in disadvantage.
For DH bikes Cube Two15 is right there at the pinnacle with SC V10 but somehow GT Fury is worse?
And bikes that the very best Rampage riders ride are not elite bikes? Like Norco Shore, YT Tues, Canyon Sender, Transition TR11, Devinci, Hyper, Commencal.... No, but someone decided Cube of all bikes is the best your money can buy and is the dream bike of all humanity.

This game is a mess and not fun to play. If you like wintersports, play Steep instead or SSX. Or anything else.

Bought this to try out the new skate mode that finally dropped. The animations look incredible, but the controls are just terrible. Had to change most of them from to their defaults to be somewhat playable, but still ain't cutting it. The fact that you do flips on flatground is a joke. Had to completely disable air rotations altogether because it's simply impossible to do a basic 180 or 360 -- it always flips! How bout putting flipping behind a button press? Also, having to press L2/R2 before flicking to do any tricks is just annoying and prevents me from doing tricks most of the time, since I seem to flick first before pressing L2/R2, causing the flick to be ignored. Moving the trick input stick in any direction does an ollie/nollie, which is a bit weird on flat as only down/up should work. Lastly, as others have mentioned, there's no goofy stance! I skate goofy IRL, so having to constantly press L1 to switch stances is incredibly frustrating. I'm sure the devs could fix this in about an hour and don't understand why they wouldn't have before release.

Chilli con carne recipe

if you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding Chilli con carne recipe you've come to the right place,

Ingredients

1 large onion
1 red pepper
2 garlic cloves
1 tbsp oil
1 heaped tsp hot chilli powder (or 1 level tbsp if you only have mild)

1 tsp paprika
1 tsp ground cumin
500g lean minced beef
1 beef stock cube
400g can chopped tomatoes
½ tsp dried marjoram
1 tsp sugar (or add a thumbnail-sized piece of dark chocolate along with the beans instead, see tip)

2 tbsp tomato purée
410g can red kidney beans
plain boiled long grain rice, to serve
soured cream, to serve

Directions

STEP 1
Prepare your vegetables. Chop 1 large onion into small dice, about 5mm square. The easiest way to do this is to cut the onion in half from root to tip, peel it and slice each half into thick matchsticks lengthways, not quite cutting all the way to the root end so they are still held together. Slice across the matchsticks into neat dice.

STEP 2
Cut 1 red pepper in half lengthways, remove stalk and wash the seeds away, then chop. Peel and finely chop 2 garlic cloves.

STEP 3
Start cooking. Put your pan on the hob over a medium heat. Add 1 tbsp oil and leave it for 1-2 minutes until hot (a little longer for an electric hob).

STEP 4
Add the onion and cook, stirring fairly frequently, for about 5 minutes, or until the onion is soft, squidgy and slightly translucent.

STEP 5
Tip in the garlic, red pepper, 1 heaped tsp hot chilli powder or 1 level tbsp mild chilli powder, 1 tsp paprika and 1 tsp ground cumin.

STEP 6
Give it a good stir, then leave it to cook for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.

STEP 7
Brown 500g lean minced beef. Turn the heat up a bit, add the meat to the pan and break it up with your spoon or spatula. The mix should sizzle a bit when you add the mince.

STEP 8
Keep stirring and prodding for at least 5 minutes, until all the mince is in uniform, mince-sized lumps and there are no more pink bits. Make sure you keep the heat hot enough for the meat to fry and become brown, rather than just stew.

STEP 9
Make the sauce. Crumble 1 beef stock cube into 300ml hot water. Pour this into the pan with the mince mixture.


info.
This great chilli recipe has to be one of the best dishes to serve to friends for a casual get-together. An easy sharing favourite that uses up storecupboard ingredients.

The gameplay is nice, almost exceptional. It's everything around it that's problematic. The world is beautiful, but the world building is so incredibly awful. Beautiful vistas are ruined by giant inflatable balloons floating around in the sky. Exploration is trivialised by a character calling you and telling you when there's something interesting nearby, with a big pop up on your map to further spoil the fun of it. The racing aspect is great but it's getting to a part when you're finally done being forced to sit through introductory cutscenes that is such an aggravating process I wouldn't blame anyone for refunding this in under 20 minutes. I shudder to think that every new player is going to be force-fed the same bland Ubisoft gruel that I had to suffer.

This is a simulated world built for simulated Gen-Z adrenaline junkies. Specifically a boomer's idea of a Gen-Z adrenaline junkie. Every single character in this game is annoying and embarrassing, there is not a single redeemable personality present. I press pause and there's my guy acting like a man-child using his skis as pretend machine guns like Rambo, or using his snowboard as a pretend bazooka, and doing the weirdest poses on post-game screens. My character behaves like the kind of person I'd be instantly annoyed with the moment they came into my vicinity. All of the cosmetics I've seen are terrible. Again, a boomer's idea of what they think Gen-Z will consider fashionable. It's the "letting your child choose their outfit for a school day" but as a whole fashion style mixed with overbearing product and brand placements.

[b]How do I know this game was designed by out of touch boomers?[/b]

1. In the home base there's a chalk board that references Thinking Foot, that old rage comic.
2. They use a cover of Gangsta's Paradise [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dnq28ZtRJhw] with a f***ing Ukelele. [/url] How dare they not use Weird Al's version?
3. Everything Brett says. Every single word. No exceptions. His entire script is full of dialogue that will make your chocolate starfish pucker up with cringe. "ThIs'Ll pUt tHe PiCkLEs In YOuR buRgER. [i]yUmmY yuM YUm.[/i]"

[b]So, now that I've gotten that off my chest, on to gameplay.[/b]

As I've said, you'll not start enjoying this game until you're a bit further along. That's not just because of the forced cutscenes, it's also because you will start out with gear that is categorically worse than end game gear by a whole lot. Turning, acceleration and breaking will all feel so incredibly sluggish until you get something halfway decent. I don't know why they keep the better content until you're 8 hours in, you'd think that's what they'd want to start out with, so I won't blame you for quitting if you do give it a try. In every race you're going to be many valuable seconds behind your peers just because you're new, not because you're bad.

You'll be able to unlock the snow racing, snow tricks, bike racing, bike tricks and flying careers for free, but the BMX career will cost extra, and I'm sure so will every career released afterwards too. You'll not find any missed opportunity for monetisation in this game. The cosmetic shop pulls the age old FOMO shtick by not showing you the entire cosmetic store at once. 

There is a handy dandy feature that lets you almost instantly get back up if you fall, and lets you rewind your last movements if you've made a mistake. However, I hoped they would've added an instant respawn button taking you to the last checkpoint since rewinding is so incredibly punishing. There are also some bugs causing you to lose races over a matter of seconds, such as getting stuck on props in the environment, and visual bugs such as [url=https://imgur.com/a/GrW1lK6]this[/url]. There is also no way to reverse on any of your equipment, so you're going to have to rewind instead, which is annoying. Also the costs that are attached to this thing are disgusting.

[b]Summary:[/b]

Good gameplay, everything else is intolerable.

I don't know if I've ever enjoyed a game quite as much as this. I grew up playing a lot of Tony Hawk's this-or-that with my older brother, and with this I feel right at home just goofing around, pulling off insane stunts and speeding downhill faster than anyone should. Between the high octane races and absolutely wild trick events, there are nearly endless ways to just... have fun. Riders Republic calls back to the days where games were just meant to push the player to do things purely for their own enjoyment, whether that be crashing into a mountainside on skis made from literal tree bark or finally nailing a trick that even the pros would fear to attempt. This game has permanently solidified itself within my favorites for all time, and it'll take hell, high water, and a lot more to pull me out of the Republic!

So I encourage all of you out there just looking for some good old mindless fun: Join the Republic, Ride on, and I'll see y'all on the slopes!

[h1] 💎         SAME GENRE COMPARISON:[/h1]
* Basic Edition still allow to access most of the racing mode
* Racing mode include: Biking racing, bike trick, ski, snowboard, wingsuit, paramotor & etc
* The wingrocket allow regenerative boost fuel
* Snowmobile is allow to ride on road, dirt, water & etc
* Each racing mode will have each outfit set
* Avatar customization include glasses & backpack
* Allow instant switch to any racing mode while traveling
* Playable when ubisoft server is stable
* Lack of compatible for Steam Deck 
* Battleye available to filter cheater

[h1]  🔊         TESTER MUST KNOW:[/h1]
* BMX = Bike Tricks for score attack mode as extra career in Gold Edition
* Helicopter Ticket = Allow fast travel to exactly pin point location, rather than 800m away
* Backtrack = Reverse falling / failure, but will not affect others and timer
* Slow internet will make game into offline mode
* Offline mode only allow to play Zen mode 
* Zen mode = Empty world with empty progress & events
* If your internet disconnect with the server, nothing is playable at all
* Personal ghost will not record unless done in leaderboard race
* Leaderboard race completion will not earn any stars
* Losing in the race will able to progress and unlock event, except not earning any star
* Ghost opponent = Real player recorded in the past 
* We are allow to have collision with any ghost

[h1]  ⚠️        RUMOR CHECKING:[/h1]
* It's an amazing experience overall ➜ Does happen if you prefer the available content
* Earning ton of in-game currency but nothing much to redeem ➜ Agree
* Many real content locked behind premium currency ➜ As usual as it

Like many other reviewers, I enjoy this game most when I turn the music and dialogue off. What is unfortunate is that you still have to sit through some unskippable cutscenes with dull-as-cardboard characters that add absolutely nothing to the game or world. With that said, I generally play this game with something else to watch or listen to in the background. This game is great if you like playing something while you kind of half-watch something else. That sounds like a subtle burn against the game, but it's actually one of its stronger features; it's very zen. There's even a "zen mode" which I haven't tried, but I can imagine what that might be like since I have found myself more than once just riding around, bombing down hills, trying not to fall for no reason other than I thought it would be cool. To make it better, if you successfully ride for a few minutes without falling you can pop open the race editor and it automatically traces where you have been going, allowing you to make the paths you've been riding into races very easily.

This is still, however, a Ubisoft game and no Ubisoft game would be complete without an overlong tutorial. Good lord, y'all. It's 2023. Please let me skip the tutorial. I'm a mature, functioning adult and I can figure it out on my own. I moved to the bay area without a job lined up having no friends in the city, and now I've been living here for 5 years. I CAN FIGURE IT OUT, UBISOFT. GET OFF MY BACK.

ANYWAY.

Everything feels pretty nice, but the controls aren't perfect. As an example, doing tricks isn't as seemless as in a lot of other games of this type. Tricks are accomplished by holding the triggers and pressing different directions on the analogue stick, but the right trigger is also used for acceleration with different vehicles, and it doesn't seem to register that you're holding the right trigger while you're in the air unless you fully release and depress it again. Because of this, I tend to do the same 4 tricks a lot which makes me just want to play more races and often avoid "freestyle" game modes. But to this game's benefit, there are a lot of races.

The progression system in this game feels good. You will earn levels as you complete events, which help you unlock new vehicles and the like. You can also unlock new things by competing in the mass races, and even if you place in the lower ranks you still get something, which makes you feel like your time isn't being wasted. You will also earn stars as you play, and season pass items unlock when you achieve certain amounts of stars, so there's a sense of accomplishment when you're doing just about anything in the game.

The real question is, is the game worth $60? My conclusion is no, but it's a really great game to get on sale. I think I bought it for less than half price with the Year 1 Pass included and I have definitely gotten my money's worth. If you like Steep and games of that style it will definitely scratch that itch. But you do gotta deal with that Ubisoft launcher though. Ugh.

After playing this game for a long while now and reaching Lvl 3500, I can safely say that this game will keep you occupied. The graphics are fair, and the gameplay is very fun, especially the downhill chaotic races and wingsuit challenges. The snow events are decent too, and overall, there's a little something for everyone in terms of gear types.

The progression in the game is flexible, allowing you to earn bucks and gear via sponsors. However, I must admit that certain rewards can be grind-heavy, and this aspect could benefit from a little rework.

The in-game store cycles every so often to keep things fresh, but it does feel rather limited in terms of the content on offer. It would be great to see more variety and options for players to explore.

The game offers plenty of unlockable gear scattered throughout the world, which adds a layer of excitement to exploring the map. However, the thrill of finding them is short-lived once you've collected all the relics. Given the size of the game's map, I was surprised that further effort wasn't made to include more Easter eggs or incorporate mini-games to extend the exploration experience.

Despite some minor flaws, the game has much to offer and is definitely worth picking up. In its current state, I would give this game a 7/10 rating. And with the addition of skateboarding on the horizon, it has the potential to earn an even higher score.

Looking ahead, I hope the team at Ubi continues to support this title further for years to come. Expanding on the content, addressing player feedback, and introducing new features can keep the game engaging and fresh for its dedicated fanbase.

Riding High with Riders Republic: Where the Mountain Roams and Laughter Explodes!

Oh, Riders Republic, you quirky devil of a game! Prepare for a wild ride, both on and off the slopes, as this cornucopia of craziness combines extreme sports, hilarious shenanigans, and outrageous fun like no other. Strap in your seatbelts (or don't, I mean, who needs 'em?) as we navigate this wacky world that will have you rolling on the floor with laughter!

First things first, get ready to look at your character—uh, your alter ego—with an equal mix of adoration and uncontrollable giggles. The customization options in this game are off the charts. From perfectly coiffed hairdos that defy gravity to outfits that scream "Wow, I paid a lot to look like this," you'll definitely be the talk of the Republic. And who can resist the allure of racing down the mountain while dressed as a giant avocado, or better yet, Santa Claus on a unicycle? Bring it on!

Now, onto the gameplay that'll make you question your life choices. Hold on tight as you hurtle down a variety of landscapes, including snowy mountains, sandy deserts, and yes, even the cityscape. But don't think these races are your typical serious business—oh no, Riders Republic encourages you to break all the rules and unleash your inner prankster. Launch yourself off cliffs into unsuspecting fellow riders, take an unexpected shortcut through a poultry farm (that's right, chickens included), or even knock someone over so expertly, they'll think they just got hit by a drunk snowman. Just remember, folks, it's not about winning—it's about making everyone cry with laughter!

Now, let's talk about the multiplayer mode. Strap it up and prepare yourself for the craziest party on virtual wheels. Join a crew of adrenaline junkies from around the world, laughing, joking, and occasionally crying together as you hilariously sabotage each other's attempts to reach the finish line. The truly beautiful thing here is that even when you're in last place, it somehow feels like a win because the pure joy and ridiculousness of the game eclipse any semblance of competitiveness. It's like a group therapy session, where the only medicine is laughter!

And can we take a moment to appreciate the bonkers events featured in Riders Republic? Whether it's a twisted game of "Capture the Llama" or a "Wing Suit Watermelon Challenge" (yes, you read that right), you'll be left questioning the sanity of the game developers with a massive grin plastered across your face. There's never a dull moment in these wild events, and if you're looking for something that will keep your friends entertained while simultaneously questioning your taste in games, look no further!

In conclusion, if you're seeking a game that combines extreme sports, outrageousness, and an endless supply of belly laughs, Riders Republic has got your back (and your sides). Unleash your inner daredevil, embrace the chaos, and prepare to be thoroughly entertained. Just make sure you have some spare pants nearby because you might just laugh them right off!

Embracing the Adrenaline-Packed Symphony of Extreme Sports in Rider's Republic!

Few games truly encapsulate the pulse-pounding excitement, freedom, and camaraderie of the extreme sports world quite like Rider's Republic. It’s as if the developers bottled up the adrenaline-infused essence of the great outdoors, and the result is a chaotic but thrilling playground of endless fun.

From the moment you first boot up the game, Rider's Republic extends a warm welcome with open-world freedom and diverse challenges that do justice to extreme sports aficionados and casual gamers alike. With picturesque landscapes stretching out as far as the eye can see, this title is more than a game - it's a digital tourism brochure for adrenaline junkies.

With the option to bike, ski, snowboard, wingsuit, and more across a wide variety of terrains, Rider's Republic is an extreme sports buffet where the main course is always thrill served fresh. Each sport boasts a unique feel and handling, making the transition from bike to board feel as exhilarating as it is seamless. Plus, the grand, mass start races are adrenaline-inducing events of pure, controlled chaos that truly test your mettle.

In terms of the social aspect, the game is a jamboree where you can connect with friends, meet other players, challenge them or simply take in the stunning views together. I can't count the times I've laughed, cheered, and shared memorable moments with players from all corners of the world. The world feels alive, active, and ripe for exploration.

Visually, Rider's Republic is a feast for the senses. It's hard not to be impressed by the lush, sprawling landscapes, the sun-kissed peaks, and the dense, mysterious forests. The attention to detail in the environment enhances the immersive experience, and I often find myself simply admiring the scenery.

As for the soundtrack, it's a spot-on blend of tracks that inspire the right amount of adrenaline rush or serenity depending on your activity. The ambient sounds of nature also contribute to a superbly immersive atmosphere.

The game is not without its challenges, both in the traditional and technical sense. Sure, there are occasional bugs and glitches, but these hardly detract from the overall experience. The developers have shown consistent effort in fixing these, and with each update, the game becomes more polished.

In nutshell, Rider's Republic is a thrilling love letter to outdoor enthusiasts and extreme sports fans. It captures the heart-stopping excitement and the indescribable freedom of these activities, making it a must-have title for any adrenaline junkie. If you're looking to conquer breathtaking landscapes and defy gravity in epic, heart-racing challenges, then it's time to strap on your helmet, and dive into the unruly, unforgettable wilds of Rider's Republic.

I want to recommend it SOOOOO MUCH, I assure you it's fun, i love bombing trails and racing downhill, I love doing tricks on my BMX, I love gliding down snow races and so on, my main gripe, my main issue is the optimization, once again let me reiterate, IT'S. SO. GOOD.

But that is IF you can play, I am not kidding you when I say I crashed a total of 14 times in the amount of time I played as I write this. I tried everything, DDU, rolling back drivers, monitoring everything related to my GPU and CPU, changed options in-game and nothing fixes it, at some point, after any amount of time, the game will crash. Were you having fun before ? Yes and you will again if you restart it but that means restarting your game and whatever race you were in, putting you back to the start of what you were doing.

It's a shame really because I really enjoy it and I find myself in a constant state of stress trying to guess WHEN I will get my progress and efforts slowed down to a halt.

I am giving it a few more days for Ubisoft to try to fix it but if you see this review is still negative after July 2023 then i gave up and refunded the game.

I seriously hope whoever will read this will be able to play for real and enjoy it because it is STUPIDLY fun, but keep in mind that this issue is not only my experience but that of many other people, as I said if this review is still negative past July 2023 then proceed with extreme caution.

I have followed this game since it was announced but originally refused to buy it since it was not on Steam. I only have a few hours on this game so far, but I wanted to get my review out while the summer sale is still going on. This game is incredibly fun. There is something for EVERYONE in this game, you truly can play your way. 

The design choices are great and I will give some examples. For instance, you have the option to "teleport nearby" to an event but it does not directly teleport you to it and I actually like this because depending on where you are at sometimes you get distracted and just start doing tricks and racing down a mountain with some random guy playing online next to you. The jetpack I thought was goofy at first, but its actually awesome because you can use it to get to events quickly or to get into crazy to reach spots and switch to a different ride and do insane stuff. Another positive consumer practice is the BMX bike. The BMX bike career (story mode) stuff is all locked behind the 1 year pass, but you have full and complete access to the BMX to run around the vast open world and skate parks doing tricks and free play. Because I got to mess around with the BMX bike freely I grew to really enjoy it and play on getting the story mode for it once I beat some of the other rides.

Long story short this game puts the players fun first in everything it does.
