Pretty fun game that covers bikes, BMX (DLC), snowboards, skiing, wingsuits and...rocketwings? It only takes one trailer to know this game doesn't take itself too seriously. That in mind you should keep your expectations to exactly that with multiple facets of the game. The physics are a little wonky, the speed absolutely outrageous for some sports and the dialogue is very "how do you do fellow kids." Not all of that is a criticism from my point of view at least but I guess this is a word of warning for anyone expecting a simulation of the sports in this game.

Do I recommend this game at full price? Probably not. It is fun but I wouldn't break out £50 for this.

I'll list out what I like and don't like about the game short 'n sweet.


Like:

[list]
[*]Open world is mostly decent with a variety of environments.

[*] Easy teleportation to get around to your preferred sport.

[*] Challenges and events keep you engaged for different content.

[*] Game gives a fantastic rush of speed. Especially participating in Mass Race events and/or going into first person.

[*] Music is ok and has a couple of stations to flick through for different genres.
[/list]


Dislike: (not so short 'n sweet)

[list]
[*] Wonky physics can sometimes be frustrating, especially if you're attempting specific tasks in an event. You will end up in a loop of restarts for some of them and that can sour the experience. The hoverboard for example is the best example of the physics going wild. Another peeve of mine is that starting a race in first-person can have you taking off at a weird angle. I have had to develop a habit of starting in third-person, then first once the race begins for some sports like snowboarding.

[*] The music is ok but the difference in volume between each track is staggering. I have attempted turn down all of the audio except music and I am still left with some tracks being as silent as a mouse. I have been relying more on Spotify to improve the experience lately.

[*] Progression (although improved somewhat in the latest patch) can be a little unclear and dull. A lot of complaints I see for this game is a lack of new clothing as you play. The game frequently throws new gear (bikes, snowboards etc) but it's purely a grind of incrementally better stats. If you like the look of a certain bike it will sadly be replaced with something slightly better in no time. I can only recommend players look at the sponsors window as soon as possible to give a sense of progression for cosmetics. There are also some items that appear in the store for in-game currency as well. Still doesn't seem like enough for me personally.

[*] Due to a lot of progression being tied to getting slightly better gear in each field, you will have to accept that in online events like Mass Races, there will be people straight up faster than you. I'd just recommend enjoying the spectacle and the track for yourself until you get better kit.

[*] The game loves to wrestle control from you after completing an event and you return to the map. I understand it's trying to highlight a new event for you but I wish it was much faster. This can be skipped with a couple button mashes at least.
[/list]

As someone who has battled with depression, I understand the need for an escape that can provide a glimmer of happiness and respite from the struggles of everyday life. In my search for a game that could lift my spirits, I discovered Rider Republic on Steam, and it turned out to be a surprisingly therapeutic experience that offered a much-needed reprieve from the depths of despair.

Rider Republic's vibrant and immersive world provided a welcome diversion from the weight of depression. From the moment I stepped into its expansive open-world environment, I was immediately captivated by the game's visually stunning landscapes and lively atmosphere. The vibrant colors, breathtaking vistas, and energetic soundtracks all worked together to create a sense of joy and freedom that had been absent from my life.

The game's wide range of activities and challenges became a valuable outlet for my emotions. Whether I was racing down mountains, pulling off exhilarating tricks on a BMX bike, or soaring through the air in a wingsuit, the sheer thrill of these experiences acted as a counterbalance to the weight I carried. Each triumph and accomplishment within the game provided a much-needed boost to my self-esteem, reminding me that I still had the capacity for joy and success.

Rider Republic's gameplay mechanics were a crucial aspect of its therapeutic value. The intuitive controls and responsive character movements allowed me to focus on the sheer enjoyment of the moment. Whether I was embarking on solo adventures or engaging in multiplayer events, the game's seamless mechanics made it easy to lose myself in the experience, temporarily setting aside the struggles of depression and embracing the thrill of the ride.

Moreover, Rider Republic's emphasis on freedom and exploration resonated deeply with me. In a world where depression can feel suffocating and limiting, the game's open-world environment provided a sense of liberation. I was able to choose my own path, set my own goals, and embrace a virtual world where the possibilities seemed endless. This sense of autonomy and agency helped me regain a sense of control, even if it was confined to the virtual realm.

Furthermore, Rider Republic's multiplayer mode fostered a sense of connection and camaraderie. Engaging with other players in events and competitions allowed me to experience a sense of community, even from the comfort of my own solitude. The shared experiences and friendly interactions served as a reminder that I was not alone in my struggles and that there were others out there facing similar challenges.

In conclusion, Rider Republic proved to be a therapeutic escape for me as someone battling depression. Its vibrant world, thrilling activities, and emphasis on freedom and joy offered a respite from the darkness, allowing me to find moments of happiness and accomplishment. While it may not provide a permanent solution to the challenges of depression, the game's ability to provide temporary relief and a sense of empowerment was invaluable. For anyone seeking a game that can lift their spirits and provide a therapeutic escape, Rider Republic is a captivating choice worth exploring.

Title: "Riders Republic: The Wild Ride that Took Me to the Dark Side"

⭐️⭐️ (2/5 Stars)

Riders Republic is a game that promised excitement, thrills, and endless fun. However, my personal experience with this game took an unexpected turn, leaving me feeling depressed, dark, and emotionally drained. Here's my account of how Riders Republic transformed me into a shadow of my former self.

At first glance, the game seemed like a thrilling adventure, with its vibrant graphics and the promise of extreme sports galore. I eagerly dove into the open world, ready to conquer mountains, soar through the skies, and engage in heart-pounding races. Unfortunately, my journey quickly turned sour.

The controls in Riders Republic felt clunky and unresponsive, making even the simplest maneuvers frustratingly difficult. It was as if the game itself was conspiring against my enjoyment, taking pleasure in my failures. The lack of precision and the constant glitches turned what should have been a joyous experience into a source of endless frustration.

Moreover, the multiplayer aspect of the game, which should have been a highlight, only exacerbated my misery. The competitive nature of the community transformed the once-exciting races into cutthroat battles filled with toxic behavior and relentless taunting. Instead of fostering a sense of camaraderie, Riders Republic seemed to bring out the worst in people, turning the online experience into a breeding ground for negativity.

The repetitive nature of the gameplay further added to my growing desolation. The challenges and events, which initially appeared diverse and engaging, quickly devolved into monotonous tasks that felt like a never-ending grind. The lack of variety left me feeling trapped in a cycle of tedium, draining my enthusiasm and extinguishing any flicker of enjoyment I had left.

As my time with Riders Republic continued, I found myself becoming increasingly withdrawn and disheartened. The game, which should have provided an escape from reality, instead became a catalyst for my dark thoughts and emotional turmoil. It was as if the relentless failures and disappointments within the game mirrored my own struggles in life, amplifying my insecurities and deepening my sense of despair.

In conclusion, Riders Republic failed to deliver on its promises of thrilling adventure and fun. Instead, it became a catalyst for my descent into depression and darkness. The clunky controls, toxic multiplayer environment, repetitive gameplay, and overall lackluster experience left me emotionally drained and feeling worse than when I started. It serves as a stark reminder of how a game, when poorly executed, can have a detrimental impact on one's mental well-being.

Disclaimer: Everyone's experience with a game can vary, and the impact on mental health can be influenced by personal circumstances. If you find yourself struggling with negative emotions, it is essential to reach out to friends, family, or professionals for support. Remember, your well-being is important, and there is help available.

This is a great game and I love it.  I love the game-play, the challenges, the huge open world and seeing the thousands of other players around me enjoying multiple sports in real-time.  The immersive environment and multiplayer events are intense, fun and nothing short of magical.  I've been excited about RR for quite a while and was excited to finally buy and play it.  There are two words why I am giving this game a negative review - Ubisoft Connect.  

As an adult who balances work, kids, wife, life etc. There is precious little time that I actually have to play games.  This is especially true for games that I like, but are inappropriate for my young children.  When a game comes out like RR that I feel I can play with my children, I get really excited to bring them into this hobby.  When my young son wakes me up early on a Saturday morning and I recommend to play a few video games, I want the game to work.  Ubisoft's madding system of negotiating multiple admin screens, dual security verification, email confirmation, internet errors, rinse and repeat, makes me just not want to play, let alone purchase any Ubisoft product in the future.  

I hope that Ubisoft can figure this out.  I stopped playing Farcry 5 about a year ago due to this exact same issue.  Compounded with an poor customer service experience, I nearly wrote off Ubisoft games at that time.  Coupled with this continued experience now with RR, I will think very hard before ever purchasing another game from Ubisoft again.

Vintage chocolate chip cookies

Ingredients
150g salted butter, softened
80g light brown muscovado sugar
80g granulated sugar
2 tsp vanilla extract
1 large egg
225g plain flour
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
200g plain chocolate chips or chunks
Method
STEP 1
Heat the oven to 190C/fan170C/gas 5 and line two baking sheets with non-stick baking paper.

STEP 2
Put 150g softened salted butter, 80g light brown muscovado sugar and 80g granulated sugar into a bowl and beat until creamy.

STEP 3
Beat in 2 tsp vanilla extract and 1 large egg.

STEP 4
Sift 225g plain flour, ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda and ¼ tsp salt into the bowl and mix it in with a wooden spoon.

STEP 5
Add 200g plain chocolate chips or chunks and stir well.

STEP 6
Use a teaspoon to make small scoops of the mixture, spacing them well apart on the baking trays. This mixture should make about 30 cookies.

STEP 7
Bake for 8–10 mins until they are light brown on the edges and still slightly soft in the centre if you press them.

STEP 8
Leave on the tray for a couple of mins to set and then lift onto a cooling rack.

RECIPE TIPS
FREEZING THE BISCUITS
If you’ve frozen the biscuits, take them out and arrange them on a lined baking sheet. Once defrosted, pop them in a medium oven 190C/170 fan/gas mark 5 and heat for 2-3 mins to crisp up. Don’t leave them too long or they’ll dry out.
STORING DOUGH
You can keep the uncooked dough in a sealed container in the fridge for up to two weeks. Simply take some out, dollop on a lined baking tray and allow to come up to room temperature for 5 mins before baking

I had a blast exploring the open world of Riders Republic with its bikes, skis, and rocket wings. The freedom to switch between activities kept me engaged and excited. The BMX tricks were satisfying, especially when I seamlessly transitioned from a high jump trick to a rail. It made me feel like a pro rider, and the trick mechanics were spot on. The presence of ghost players in the world added a dynamic and competitive feel. Racing alongside them and seeing them perform tricks created a lively and thrilling experience. The mass races were chaotic but incredibly fun. Once I learned the maps and improved my skills, aiming for a top 10 or even top 3 finish was exhilarating.

Overall, Riders Republic delivered an action-packed adventure with diverse sports, seamless tricks, and thrilling races. It's a game that kept me entertained and hooked from start to finish.

I did not think the reviews here talking about how bad the tutorial is were serious but I promise you, it's one of the worst tutorials I've ever played. It's way too long, throws too much at you at once, and never lets you take a break to actually go enjoy the game until you complete it all the way through. It is UNBEARABLY LONG and tedious with the worst dialog of all time. I legitimately almost refunded it because it was that bad and I am NOT the kind of person to do such a thing. If you did refund, I do not blame you.

That said, if you made it through that agonizing process, you'll find an excellent game. I LOVED this game's predecessor, Steep. Played it here on PC and even more on PS4, completing every event on the latter. This game really steps up what that game already did pretty well in my opinion. Switching between sports seamlessly is really neat to experiment with and it makes the map effortless to move around in. The map is HUGE and full of both bots and real players anywhere you go; giving the ridge a real sense of life to it. There's a Zen Mode where you can explore the map without any events so you can simply just vibe while taking in the gorgeous landscapes. It's a beautiful world to just take in when you're not thrashing every inch of it with your sick tricks. The base game has plenty to keep you busy, but I'm really enjoying the DLC content so far. The BMX and Hoverboards are a blast to tool around with and give me Tony Hawk and Dave Mirra/Matt Hoffman vibes for sure.

Snowboarding and skiing are back with a different trick system which is both hit and miss for me personally. It is nice that they let you switch out control schemes on the fly at any point (even mid race!) and they even included the old Steep controls as well. It really takes a minute to get used to the controls, but it did click for me eventually. Wing suits and Rocket suits are back too and still fun to use. I will say the Rocket suit events are incredibly hard at times and even borderline unfair in some cases, so be prepared to redo them a ton of times. Wing suits got a bit of a rework and they handle more arcadey but in a very positive way by letting you gain some altitude to keep a line going via the boost button. It does take some of the danger of wing suiting that made it so satisfying and dangerous in Steep, but overall it's a welcome addition.

The downsides in this game basically boil down to a classic answer: Ubisoft. They'll nickel and dime you as always and the Ubi launcher is horrific. The DLC is, again, pretty fun, but it's not really cool to lock new sports behind a paywall. If you're going to add new sports, everyone should be able to use them. It's a scummy tactic that is anti player, plain and simple. I've experienced some stability issues where I've clipped through halfpipes and had plenty of bugs happen in my time, but never anything completely game breaking. It's caused me to have to restart events, but that's about as bad as its gotten. Usually a bug just makes me chuckle and it's fixed by just resetting my character. It still sucks, but polish is rare in AAA games unfortunately.

This game is FUN at the end of the day. It's a blast once you're able to access it. It's a wonderful sequel to Steep I've always wanted personally and it seems like there's plenty of content on the horizon still to come. Even if the people on the map are bots, it's really cool to see this active and thriving world as you're exploring it. Having someone do a flip over me on their snowboard while I'm in a bike race never gets old, and seeing active races in real time going on in the distance gives the world a little more vitality that other open world games lack nowadays. Worth picking up on sale, especially the deluxe edition with the extra DLC sports if you're interested.

The game itself is pretty good, the many different rides you can use and being able to see all the dozens of other players real or not riding around with you was super cool.

I also previously played this game through the Ubisoft Connect launcher itself sometime last year, and had save data in the cloud that game downloaded from there. I wanted to delete the save data the game downloaded from there previously so I could start over and get a grip on how to play the game again. There's no option to delete your save data within the options in game, and no matter how many times I would disable cloud saves and delete the data on my PC, it would still download every time. No articles online helped either.

I ended up contacting Ubisoft asking if they could delete my save data and help me start over, to which they literally replied that they could not. I wish I could start the game over again so I could remember how to play, but Ubisoft is forcing me to be stuck.

UPDATE: I can not recommend this game in it's current state, This is unacceptable for a game that is charging people 60-120$ with no sale. I am going to list some of the major issues i have with this game.The game can become hard locked at times putting you in either an infinite load screen or locking you into a screen where you would push enter to start the match but nothing happens, this has happened to me 4 times now over just a few hours. The game also has crashing issues as well, seems to happen at random. Server stability is not good at all! every time a player joins in on the game world you are in it causes a pretty bad lag/freeze spike to occur, if you have cross play on like most people normally would to have more players around the stutters/lag/freeze spikes are constant due to many people constantly leaving/joining the game world. I found that turning cross play off is necessary if you would like to cut down on the freeze/lag/stutters by like 80%. Obviously the down side to this is there will not be nearly as many people in your world, but hey i think it is worth it purely for better stability server wise. The other issue i have with the game even though it is not game breaking it looks god awful! i mean i don't know what happen here but holy hell it is bad! textures always fail to load in on time so you are always seeing unfinished textures along with many visual bugs that occur, as far as i am aware i do not believe the console version of this game had any of these issues according to what i found of the internet. Now i want to talk about how bad the controls are for keyboard and mouse users like myself, it is bad i mean really bad, it almost makes me wounder how much they tested before they decided to launch this game on PC. There are even tricks that you just can not do with a keyboard at all, like a nose manual on a bike or a wheelie, the game tells you push s or w SLOWLY to do said trick, how the F do you push a key on a KEYBOARD SLOWLY? yeah anyway point proven. Not everyone owns a compatible controller like myself, and no i am not going to go spend 60+ $ on a controller that i will rarely ever use. The other issue that i just recently started running into is the random disconnects from the game serves that occur, you can be in the middle of a race/competition and then all the sudden you get disconnected from the server for no reason at all. I am honestly so confused why people are giving this game a thumbs up in it's current state, the game feels like a half baked product, i mean seriously i have played early access games that are much more stable/visually better than this game. If you are willing to still play this game despite it's issues then i would say pick it up well it has a deep sale like i did, thankfully i only lost out on 30$ instead of 120$ for the ultimate edition. I will list my PC specs below for the people reading this thinking it is my computer being a potato. I forgot to add that almost everything in this game seems to be a pay with real life money to unlock. (like the bmx bikes)


My PC Specs: 3080GPU 32 gigs of RAM i7 8700K CPU

They want $20 for a bmx bike (the ability to buy and use a bmx) and you start the game riding a bike! you gotta pay for the hoverboard too. i wouldve never bought this had i known. The controls are fucken terrible. Def the worst controls Ive had to put up with in ANY racing game. Its buggy and does a bad job of placing in a fair position after you mess up. On top of that some races aren't designed too well. The floaty gravity will work against you at times. avatar customization is lousy, but at least there's a fair amount clothes to cover up that ugly face. NEVER buy this at full price, or better not at all. there's better games available for each sport they try to cram in.

Riders Republic is a good game in spite of itself.

There's an unskippable 45 minute long tutorial. Every single line of dialogue is atrocious. The music selection is pretty limited. Everything interesting for the character customization is locked behind a paywall. The trick system is straight up bad.

If you crank the dialogue volume down to zero and get past the tutorial, you'll find a game with an incredible sense of speed and an absurd amount of ways to ride. Ride bikes downhill. Take a ski jump. Use a jetpack to soar through the sky. All of this can be done in one continuous run, as the game lets you swap equipment while playing. I've flown my jetpack at breakneck speeds towards a ramp, swapped to a bike, and before landing the jump, switched over to a big wheeled tricycle, because why not?

There's an absolutely ludicrous amount of routes to ride, and every 30 minutes, a 64 player event can be joined that is utter chaos in the best ways.

Pick it up on sale. Some of the equipment is DLC, and you'll have a better time if you pick some of it up. Also, skateboards are coming soon.

Here is my edited version:

I have played this game for many hours now, and my opinion of it has only improved over time. It is an incredibly addictive game that you can easily hop in and out of for both short and long play sessions.

THE INTRO: The intro can be as short as a couple hours or as long as 20 hours depending on how quickly you progress. As a casual player, I'm not even sure what specifically constitutes the "intro" other than unlocking all the sports, which does take a while. For some, the zen mode where you freely ride alone may be the most enjoyable.  

CONTROLS: The controls have a learning curve and took me a while to get used to. They are a mix of SSX and Tony Hawk. I originally hated the controls and repeatedly changed them to find a better setup. What ultimately helped was mapping all the tricks to the D-pad and the original D-pad controls to the letter buttons. This helped me understand how the tricks actually work by directing your rider left, right, up and down. Once I grasped that, I switched back to the default controls, and the letter mappings made more sense. This method may not work for everyone but helped me tremendously. 

MULTIPLAYER: Playing with friends can be frustrating at first but is enjoyable. You can ride together in the open world and challenge each other. Finding each other initially is difficult, so I recommend turning on the visible line in the accessibility settings which draws a line between players within 20 feet of each other. This is especially helpful when you're still learning how to control your rider. 

One thing you can't do in multiplayer is complete tasks together. Like to progress through the actual game you have to play every track solo and finish it at least once alone. You can always challenge friends and build your own track, but it would be very nice if I could somehow do some of the actual missions along with my friend if I've already completed them. Would be fun to watch or to be able to do it along with a friend while we both unlock things independently. Something like that? Just kinda sucks to kinda always bounce in and out of social groups. The multiplayer battle modes are fun, but I haven't really explored them much. There really is a lot going on in this game, which is why the intro is so long. It kind of needs to be.

DIFFICULTY: The difficulty is customizable. Easy settings are highly recommended for the first couple of hours as you get used to the speed and controls. The difficulty provides a real thrill once you progress to the pro levels. A small mistake at high speeds can end a race in an instant, which can be panic-inducing but feels extremely rewarding when you succeed. Reseting your rider after a crash is immediate, but the falls can be jarring enough that I often leave my rider lying on the ground for a few moments.  

MAP/GRAPHICS: The map and graphics are gorgeous, similar to Red Dead Redemption's landscape and variety. Instead of riding horses, you can use almost anything else to navigate the terrain, and more options will likely be added. The changing time of day and weather enhances the evolving feel of the game.

SOUND DESIGN: The sound design is fantastic. I love hearing the skis on the snow, the wind, and ambient nature sounds. While there is a lot of good music, especially 90s alternative rock, I prefer using Spotify to play my own playlists. The ability to incorporate custom Spotify playlists into games would be amazing.

As others have noted in their reviews, the annoyingness of the radio DJs and announcers have that weird overly happy vibe as if I'm being talked to like I'm a 10-year-old who thinks hoverboards are totally rad. I see why they did it. It's a fun and playful game that you shouldn't take too seriously. However, I just wish it was a bit more for adults in some ways while retaining litterally everything else other than the Voice Overs. 

*I used AI to edit/clarify points made in my review.

I wish I could give this a mixed review instead of a thumbs up, but it's definitely not that bad of a game so it doesn't deserve a thumbs down. First, if your graphics driver is out of date, expect this game to crash randomly a LOT. I didn't figure that out until about 20 hours into the game, and I had barely any resources online telling me otherwise. On to the game...

It's a little annoying, but the gameplay is fun. I really enjoyed steep and was hoping that this would live up to its reputation, but there's a lot of things missing from steep that didn't carry over here which I really don't understand. In Steep, you progressively gained money to buy your character different boards or skis, jackets, hats, etc. A lot of the equipment wasn't behind a paywall that's also extremely limited depending on what's being sold that week in the shop. Everything was there, and if it wasn't you had to unlock it. I truly enjoyed that about steep because I could even change the different boots I had on my board, rather than a complete set. I hate that they changed that system into this, where all of your gear is ranked and some gear are more obviously better than others, creating a meta that top players would use just to get the fastest times instead of showcasing pure skill. 

Second, graphics are worse in riders republic than steep. I don't even know how that's possible, but the snow trails that players would leave in deep snow don't even show that well in this game compared to steep. It's obvious that the game was made half-assed with the intention of living up to steep, but doesn't even bother to retain some of the best parts about it.

Lastly, like many other Ubisoft games now, the unskippable dialogue and cringeworthy writing is terrible. Everything is supersaturated like some sort of advertisement for a hot wheels game. Ubisoft has a very unclear target demographic for this game since it fails to master the racing and extreme components to the hardcore players, and fails to make it arcadey for the kids. It has a little bit of an identity crisis, but hey, that's most of Ubisofts games nowadays.

As an aspiring game developer who wants to enter Ubisoft's NEXT competition for upcoming developers to win an internship there, man I don't know about working for them someday. I'm giving this a generous 7/10 only because I love MTB and Snowboard racing in real life.

Every ingredient's there for it to be the ultimate extreme sports title, but it's a product rather than an experience.

The controls are obtuse, often I find that movement is unresponsive and it's a coin flip whether my attempt to do a corkscrew passes through to the game or not. The default bindings are uncomfortable for every scheme. I had to play around for half an hour to find a setup that worked for me but the problem is there's way too many assignable actions for a controller to handle comfortably. A big problem is the camera, stationed directly behind the player or to one side, and is only manually accessible with one control scheme. You can adjust the FOV slightly which helps but there's no adjustable zoom. I wiped out more times to objects I couldn't see in my path or around corners, and even lack of information from where I'll be able to land safely after a jump than from my own incompetence. God forbid you use first person.

The events themselves are pretty miserable. I tried 25~ish on expert for a semblance of challenge but I found myself fighting more against the poorly conveyed terrain and horribly restrictive checkpoints than the AI ghosts I was racing against. The "pop 5 balloons" objectives were particularly awful, most requiring carefully manoeuvring dangerous terrain that lead away from checkpoints, which are mandatory lest the game force rewind you and waste a huge amount of time. At that point you might as well restart the event. The first few downhill bike races the game suggests are fun, fluid and persuaded me to continue playing over my Steam refund timer, which I deeply regret. If I had to compliment one thing it would be the BMX segments, which appear to be the only activity designed with player experience in mind. The overall design philosophy leans more on the serotonin from "the one good run" instead of making sure the player has a good time doing anything they want. If you don't take the game seriously it has a nice, casual appeal.

This product is why I wish Steam would implement a middle recommendation. I can't say I would recommend it but it's not a bad product. For starters, it's not very consumer friendly - upon launch, you'll be spending the next 48 minutes to complete the tutorial - that seems stupid, as you cannot skip them. Optimization is iffy, with huge frame drops and stuttering consistently and makes the experience not all that good. And the final one is that the game is from Ubisoft, which forces you to use their own service/launcher, which is a stupid implementation and seems to cause more issues than anything. Overall, besides those issues, the game is pretty good, it feels good to play and is pretty fun to either race competitively or mindlessly ride around.

The game overall is very mid. The map is amazing and you can tell thats where all the resources went into but the gameplay is meh at best and all the fun rides and stories are locked behind an additional pay wall. The game just seems like one big cash grab for Ubisoft. Thumbs down

Normally I'd start with a preamble about how shit recent ubisoft ports are on steam, how they seem to have issues with crashing, every ubisoft game that has been dumped on steam after being an epic exclusive has had issues with crashing, even far cry 6 which was a pretty decent port had some crashing issues. So Riders Republic is a game I was very disappointed with because it wasn't on steam, I'd recently sold the last of my consoles so I couldn't play it at all (as I'm strictly steam only), needless to say when ubi started dropping games on steam again I was hoping they'd release this, well it's taken it's time but I finally got my wish, and I'm not disappointed. 

This might be one of the best ubi games in recent times, look I know ubi is a shit company run by cunts but I still find myself enjoying quite a large portion of their library but I'm not blind to the criticism. I get most of the games they push out suffer with open world bloat or are too similar but this game is different, yes it's open world but it's so fresh and unique I can't but help love this, especially when extreme sports games aren't as common anymore unless you look at the indie scene.

So this is an open world live service game that let's you freely swap between various sports, you can do this on the fly and it's so incredibly satisfying. There are so many events and races and cool mp gamemodes to play. I have been playing nonstop and managed to finish the battle pass and getting myself 1200 stars, rookie numbers in the grand scheme but hopefully a testament of my enjoyment for the game.

They are adding skateboards soon and I cannot wait, sure this game gatekeeps content as dlc but considering I paid so little I'm not too mad to throw a few more bucks at them for a fully fleshed out career, if it's half as good as the bmx update then I'll be happy. 

The game isn't perfect, the tutorial is too hand holdy and the voice acting is the most cringe shit ever but man this game is so fun to play. 

Ubisoft you're a shit company but you put out an absolute banger of a game with riders republic and I'm glad it's finally home on steam.

Unfortunately, my experience with the game has been far from enjoyable. I feel compelled to share my thoughts, as I believe it's important to provide honest feedback.

First and foremost, one of the major issues plaguing Riders Republic is its poor optimization. The game suffers from frequent FPS drops and overall instability, making it frustrating to play. It's disheartening when a game fails to deliver a smooth and seamless experience, especially in today's gaming landscape where optimization should be a priority.

Moreover, I found the story and voice acting in Riders Republic to be lackluster at best. The narrative feels pale and fails to engage the player, while the voice acting often falls into the realm of cringey and annoying. A captivating story and strong voice performances can significantly enhance a game, but sadly, Riders Republic misses the mark in this aspect.

The map itself is plagued by lag issues, which only exacerbate the overall gameplay problems. Constant lagginess makes it frustrating and at times impossible to enjoy the game fully. Additionally, the incessant pop-ups further impede gameplay, making it a cumbersome experience to even attempt any meaningful progression.

One of the few redeeming aspects of Riders Republic is the sports it offers. When they work as intended, they do provide moments of genuine fun and excitement. It's a shame that the positive aspects of the game are overshadowed by the numerous technical and design flaws.

To make matters worse, the game took an inordinate amount of time to release on Steam, raising expectations among the community. However, it ultimately fails to deliver on the anticipation it generated. The long wait only adds to the disappointment of the overall experience.

In conclusion, I cannot recommend Riders Republic in its current state. The lack of optimization, subpar story and voice acting, laggy map, and intrusive pop-ups hinder the potential enjoyment that the sports aspect of the game offers. It's a shame to see a game with such potential fall short on so many fundamental levels. I hope the developers take note of these issues and work towards addressing them to provide a more satisfying experience for players in the future.

A range of event types to participate in. The Mass Race is pure madness and fun. Besides competing in events, taking the time to explore the world is quite fun/relaxing. Quirky story-line characters that fit the Hollywood stereotypes of "extreme sports" personalities (not for everyone). Downside is the store if you want to unlock all the cosmetics you're looking at spending some real life money. But the game has been out long enough to have lots to unlock if you're new. Not a fan of the radio being drowned out by the game's sound effects. I understand it's there for the illusion of speed and intensity but sometimes you just want to listen to the good radio mix the game offers. I tend to put most sounds at 40% and music at 100%. Definitely not a game for everyone but a must for that nostalgia of this genre of game.

My next option is to refund but i definitely don't want to because it is a very good game from what I've played on PS4. I don't recommend purchasing unless on sale or the bugs are fixed. until then i cant give this game a positive review. Fun fun

POSITIVES:
I grew up on Tony Hawk's Pro Skater. This game brings me back big time with the BMX and the snowskate, stringing together combos and racking up tons of points. It feels like a spiritual successor in that sense. Skateboarding is coming in September, and if it's anything like BMX, it's gonna be great. Mountain biking is my 2nd favorite behind BMX. The sense of speed is there when going down huge hills. The Mass Races with 64 live players are a highlight of this game. Hectic and fun as hell.

It's a chill game, messing around in free roam is where I spend most of my time, but there are tons of maps and events to play. Speaking of maps, it's GIGANTIC, smashing together several real life national parks into one.

NEGATIVES: 
The controls are pretty unintuitive, and the tutorial SUCKS (30 minutes at least). But power through those and you'll have a good time. Also, BMX career/events/sponsors cost money. I recommend getting the season pass when it goes on sale, or just buying the Gold Edition (also when it goes on sale) if you want to get the most out of BMX. Otherwise you'll still have access to a few BMX bikes, but only in free roam.

Forza Horizon and Steep had a lovechild and this is what became of it.  I had a little fun for a little while and I got it for $15 on sale so I can't complain about that; however, learning that I would have to pay another $40 for a BMX career wasn't fun.  Seeing guys riding around with smoke masks and cool features that I would have to pay extra for wasn't fun.  Each unlock in the career sticks you with a bit of newer slightly better gear and it's a pretty fixed path for the people that don't want to pay extra ... that wasn't much fun either but whatever.  I had fun goofing off and falling on my face, or rocketing around in the jetwing for a little bit but it's not worth more than the $15 I paid for it.

Game crashes on avatar creation. Apparently my i7 CPU (4x3.5GHZ*2threads) is to old (no AVX2 and this requirement was added with BMX path). But beta was working smooth on it... Well, no problem. REFUND. If you don't want my money, get lost Ubisoft.

dope
couldn't get passed that endless ubisoft tutorial cringe hell.

unskippable (annoying) dialogue, unskippable map updates (i apparently unlocked about 30 new events and it wasted almost 10 minutes of my time FORCING me to watch it bounce back and forth on the map) AND a full 2 minute long "update" section every time you complete an event.(showing unlocks, IN THE CORNER OF YOUR SCREEN,  YOU JUST ARENT ALLOWED TO MOVE)

the control schemes are weird, something I could probably get used to if I played the game more, but the rest of the game gives me 0 desire to do so. The mechanics are almost unintuitive, and are sometimes unresponsive, I found myself "dying" a lot because I would try to jump. and wouldn't, then hit the button again and the game registered as a backflip.

The soundtrack is annoying, i heard the same 5 songs multiple times in 1 hour of gameplay.

As far as character customization goes, there is very little (aside from clothing which is all great)
All of the character face models look like they have been beaten within an inch of their life.
All of the hair models look atrocious, and there arent many options to begin with (I have a common male hairstyle, and It was not in the game, so I made my character bald)

The gameplay itself (once you get to experience it) is honestly rather fun, but the issues that plague this game quickly creep up and make you want to turn it off.

Among a few other things that I have forgotten, this game was a disappointment.

I have seen footage of this game, and have wanted to play it for so long. After finally having done so, I refunded the game after an apparent 1.4 hours.

TL;DR Sucky mechanics, dialogue is awful and unskippable, character design (both npc and customizable player) is AWFUL, map is unintuitive, and many other issues plague this game that is otherwise mostly enjoyable. I refunded.

The tutorial is abhorrent, the game has sub par graphics, and it gets kind of boring after a couple hours. For the sale it has as of writing this, $15 isn't terrible. But for $60 after the sale ends, better use of that money is to set it on fire. Same goes for the two "better" editions, you get some clothes, some special bikes, and a special jet pack that you immediately will replace after the first air race. I regret buying the Ultimate edition, waste of $30.

For the first hour of game play, the tutorial grabs you and doesn't let you do anything else but it. I wanted to explore and learn for myself how to ride and such, but instead got force-fed this crap.
The game, for being a recently released game, does not look pretty (I am using max graphics). Landscapes in the distance will look like un-rendered blotches and bikes sometimes won't render in right. 

Game play is alright, by what I heard its like Steep but downgraded; i haven't played Steep so i can't say much about comparisons, but IMO the bike racing is really the only interesting sport in this game. It's pretty good, the game does capture the feeling of speed pretty well. and thats it, thats what it really only hit well with. The snowboarding is just tricks off ramps, the jet packs are"race through the giant gates", wingsuits are just flying close to the ground for points, and thats it really. Theres also bike stunts and snowboarding racing, but they're pretty average too.

Another thing is the micro-transactions, this game is full of it. Most clothes, 2 careers (sports) and a event pack cost money to access them. Yeah, they're adding content to the game, but its behind a paywall of course.

Glitches are common place, I've fallen down into the void many times on the bike, I've soft-locked multiple times while restarting the jet pack races and my character like turning into an eldritch horror after landing a jump. 

I really wanted to give Ubisoft a chance again, but I instead wasted my money on an average game full of micro-transactions with subpar graphics. (Will admit though, the 64 player races are kinda fun and chaotic.)

[h2]Ubisoft being Ubisoft[/h2]
In-game purchases to customize your characters, repetitive gameplay that, while entertaining at first, becomes dull and boring after a few hours. Mountain Biking is my favourite activity in the game and in real life. It was fast-paced and exhilarating, while the controls for stunts and other gear were a little finicky I thought it was great. 

The whole game feels like one long drawn out tutorial with cringe worthy dialog and personalities. It's best to mute everything for the music and dialog while listening to your own tracks on spotify or playlists. 

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Great arcade modes, but as a full on community based game very shallow and lacking in many things. Mass Events are about the most fun part of the whole thing, but they happen every half hour or so and there is not much in between besides doing challenges.

The amount of weak delivery from 'characters' in this game is unbearable. One liners, dry jokes, artificial excitement and just general poor writing makes it feel like your jamming nails into your ears. "Woah! that was radical! Now that you have done that challenge, why dont you skidaddle to the next event and show everybody who is boss!" .... How FUCKING OUT OF TOUCH CAN A COMPANY BE? Its like my uncle at the family BBQ trying to use slang and shit... Like your dad saying "on god" or "no cap".. Total horse$H!T

Seriously, absolute worst tutorial ever. For that alone the game deserves to not be recommended. Tutorial, rushing it as fast as you possibly can, is 40mins. And filled with low quality video's, and voiced by a bunch "Cool" and "Radical" individuals attempting to hype up the game.
Who ever designed the map to slowly go to every new event that's become available to you after you unlock them, in a row, and unskippable, should be fired. I ended up Alt-F4'ing after sitting there for 3 straight minutes watching the map uncontrollably go to each new event one at a time. First 45mins of this game was more then enough. Not even worth the sale price at 75% off. Feels like a downgraded Steep game, where they attempted to tie in features of The Crew 2, but instead filled with a bunch of simulated characters to pretend to be real players, when it's practically 98% ai's riding around. The funniest part is they are all on paths, and if you sit still for more then a minute, which your forced to on several occasions, you can very quickly tell the game isn't full of people, it's full of ai. With the worst tutorial, clunky UI, and bad controls.

It's honestly Steep, but made slightly worse in all areas, and filled with gimmicks. Go look at the 2 videos on the steam store page, and ask yourself, how much of it is actual gameplay, and how much of it is random showoff crap to try and get your attention. I feel ashamed purchasing this.

EDIT: Others weren't joking about Micro-Transactions. I started up the game again here to give it another go, and pretty much everything, including various events, have to be purchased with micro-transactions. Heck the majority of them cost more then the base game.

What is Rider's Republic? Imagine an Open World Game where you can fly around in a rocket, switch to a bike, switch to a snow board on a mountain, then go sprinting down a hill going 160 miles per hour in a speed bike, thats rider's republic, you can do this in groups of 6, or just solo go to any of the events with others, its pretty intense! and its getting skateboarding!

We got people playing it and a discord if you want to join - https://discord.gg/FEC7uFcz
also live every night on twitch - twitch.com/catnaps_tv

This turned out to be incredibly fun and challenging enough to feel like a pro when you finally nail that tough event after many tries. And when you don't wanna sweat the technique, just rocket wing or flying squirrel-yourself down a mountain river and transform mid-air onto a bike and move along.

Riders Republic is dope. It’s like Ubisoft told Travis Pastrama “We need you to make Forza Horizon but for extreme outdoor sports”. With the recent announcement of Skateboarding launching in September, Riders Republic just has tons of content. Snowboarding, Skiing, BMX, Downhill Biking, Road Biking, Freestyle Snowmobiling, Ultralights, Wingsuits, Jetpacks, you won’t find yourself bored. For $15 on sale this game is an absolute steal and I can’t recommend it enough. 
Graphics are great, the soundtrack is good, the sound design is supreme. I can’t say I’ve played enough to have any real criticism about the game. They even include a “Zen Mode” if you just want to vibe and hit the slopes solo. 

10/10 would shred the gnar again

tl;dr this is a mixed review. I want this kind of game with biking, skiing, boarding but it's bloated with so much garbage. Would only recommend at the $15 sale price and even then only if you can put up with typical Ubisoft bloat and greed.

On the surface, this looks like it could be a ton of fun, but as someone who has put a fair amount of hours into the game Descenders, the control scheme completely throws me off. It will take more time than I'm currently willing to commit to acclimate. Also, the movement feels really clunky and automated, even with everything set to manual controls. It just doesn’t give me that "wow, I can’t believe I landed that" factor like the game Descenders does.

Edit: BMX aside, I will say that the wing-suiting is fairly enjoyable, due to the visually pleasing environment. Ubisoft could definitely make a standalone game based off this, if they made the physics a bit more realistic.

PROS: Great game. Tight feeling controls, low frustration, vast map of activities. I miss SSX and this helps with that. A good arcade sports game.
PROS: More wild bears than Forza. Lot's more.
CONS: Worst writing in video game history and yes I count the badly translated games. It's embarrassing to listen to. The best way to describe it is a very strong "Hello fellow kids vibe." only with more cringe. Try-hard with a vengeance. 
CONS: Overly greedy cash shop.

Other than that, fantastic.

I played quite a bit of Steep and was excited for Rider's Republic since it was announced and was very excited at the potential for another Steep-like game! After its announcement I didn't hear anything about it, but when I found out it was on sale I picked it up for $20, and honestly I don't think I would have paid more for it. I'll talk about it from a Steep fan POV as well as a regular player POV.

In relation to Steep it's an okay Steep successor; it has similar features (like session markers, custom race content, etc) that Steep fans will like and the gameplay is roughly similar to Steep but with new sports and gear to use. There's a noticable absence of the Bone Collector progression and instead seems to focus you more on 'getting good' instead of crashing in fun ways, which is a little disappointing.

However, comparisons to Steep aside I think even for a general audience there's a lot of UX and game design decisions feels either a little sloppy or strangely directionless, and its microtransaction economy is one of the worst I've seen in a Ubisoft title to date.

UX: When dropping into the game it immediately puts you into a race scenario, and you can tell they wanted to get you directly into the action. But after that begins a series of forced introductory cutscenes and missions that took me about 1.5 hours to complete. Some cutscenes I could skip through, while others (like video call or ones that play when you unlock new content on the map) force me to sit through them even when I'm not interested. Generally speaking it feels like the directors couldn't decide if they wanted the player to get in on the action right away or onboard them slowly, and it ends up falling flat on its butt on both fronts.

Gameplay: Some mechanics just feel sloppy or purposeless.

For example there's a 'rewind' mechanic like Forza that lets you rewind your progress at any time to a previous state in the race. The game seems to tout this as a thing you should be using, but I've found it to be very intrustive. Firstly, it resets you facing forward, even if you were turning, which has the possibility of sending you careening in a different direction from your rewinded point. It also doesn't preview your momentum very well, which can make it hard to know if you should be breaking, gliding or accelerating at your restored point. It also doesn't stop the timer during some race types, which makes the prospect of using it instead of just restarting the race pointless if you're on any difficult aside from the easiest one.

There's also swarms of AI riding around the world, and following them can show you where major paths and courses are in the open world. It's a neat technical feature at a glance - some of them just jump around in place or mimic the behaviour of players randomly goofing off. However you'll soon notice that they phase in and out of existence at the start and end of their lines like some kind of Matrix glitch, and if you stand in place you'll see that they're all actually the same characters repeating the exact same action over and over on a short loop. What makes them extremely unbearable is that there's some sources and challenges that require pinpoint precision which become 1000x harder when you have a swarm of 12 AI jumping around and flying this way and that in front of your screen. There's no option to turn them off, they add little, and get old very quickly.

Realization: What was nice about Steep was that generally the 'realization' and justification for the world was pretty minimal. You were just a person on a mountain doing sports and events. For some reason the direction here decided it needed to double-down on rationalizing this premise - like some Ubisoft Executive looked at the premise and complained that it 'didn't make enough sense' or something - and it hurts the game so much.

Now there's a cast of characters who all talk with dialog and "cool" lingo written as though a 45 year old man tried to imagine how a 15 year old talks (bless the writers, I can only imagine finding 100 different ways to write dialog basically just telling you to "Go play [x] event" or "You did a good job" would be such a pain in the butt).

The world itself is also full of branded tie-ins, which I understand is standard for Sports Games but feels out of place here - most Fast Travel points have a Ford F-150 in front of them framed perfectly in camera when you travel to them (which you'll be doing a lot) while CLIF is featured in the main HUB and Prada has a line of in-game events you can complete. It just feels aggressively integrated for even a sports title.

I personally thought the art direction in previews looked cool at the time, but after playing for a while it felt really aimless. The world is a...eco-tech-neon-punk 'rider's paradise' but it's really difficult to nail down what the 'look' its going for even is. Players are given clothing items to either look like a regular joe or a character straight out of Fortnite. It's whiplash inducing and generally a look that feels like Ubisoft Direction generally just didn't have a solid vision for what the game's world should look like at all and it really shows. Maybe some Executive looked at Watch Dogs Legion and said 'idk make it like that I guess'.

World: The mountains, forests, canyons outside of the manmade stuff is pretty, however I find that unless you're travelling on the more level defined paths in the world it's easy to bump into stuff and feel like you're in the wrong place. I found Steep was much more forgiving when it comes to exploration and 'carving out' your own path in the world, but here if you go the wrong way it's much more likely to feel like you're *going the wrong way*

Economy: This is the most painful part to me. I understand games are expensive to make and am typically skeptical when people complain about game pricing, but I do think Rider's Republic is one of the weirder monetization schemes out there.

It's a premium game you pay full price (~$75) for, but its in-game economy is structured like an MMO. Most gear like bikes and skis are earned through events which is nice, but I noticed I played 5 hours and had no new cosmetics and a ton of 'Bucks' to spend. Steep rewarded cosmetics fairly regularly, so I was surprised I hadn't got anything new and decided to check out the in-game shop.

I checked the in-game shop and noticed that I could afford exactly 1 outfit from the shop with my in-game money, but the selection was really limited. There was maybe 16 items in total and out of those 16 maybe 11 of them were premium-currency only. I looked some stuff up online and learned that not only is this normal, the shop also cycles content *weekly*, so if you don't like anything in the shop that week you better be ready to come back next week and try again.

It's an arbitrary restriction that you can tell they lifted from F2P MMO models to enforce user retention and get people coming back with their friends again and again, but I need to reiterate that this is a paid game that costs $80 regularly. I don't think I'd play this on a *weekly* basis, especially not just to see what's in the store, and since I already paid for the game I'm doubtful I'd every buy the premium currency. This cosmetic store would be fine as an optional side-thing for die-hard fans, but as a casual player it's crazy that I now have tons of money in-game, nothing to spend it on and no cosmetics I feel like buying - it seems like a massive failure in the economy's design. I hesitate to call things 'greedy' but it really does feel like it's overstepping goodwill here.

TL;DR It's a fine (maybe a little worse) successor to Steep that has gameplay annoyances which compound into larger issues, hostile economy design and what feels like sloppy direction on what could have been a much cooler idea.

As usual with Ubisoft, this game could've been a star, but due to a poor gaming company who only cares about lining their pockets, i am already done with this game. I am so very glad I only spent 30 bucks on the ultimate addition (Down from over 100 dollars). Because you get rocket ski's, a rocket bike, a absolutely poor amount of cosmetics, and that's it... for about 40 dollars more than retail price you get a couple cool vehicles, and about 7 cosmetics. You also get a game that's about as much fun as eating a pile of dirt. The game is poorly optimized, but after playing Watch Dogs: Legion, i knew that good old Ubisoft would drop the ball on that one. The biggest issue is that I feel like I have absolutely no control over my rider. I will hold the turn button for a solid two seconds before my character turns, whenever I decide to go up a hill, (with my bike with literal rocket boost), it will almost always autocorrect my character to either be going sideways or straight down back where I came from. It takes a overly considerable amount of effort to straighten my rider to go up the hill. It should be as simple as me accelerating my bike, and dodging obstacles. My character will randomly get caught on a flat piece of hill, or start hopping around more than a rabbit on a damn trampoline. Game is absolutely unfun, the tutorial takes almost a whole HOUR to complete, and it is forced. You barely get to touch the game the whole time, not to mention afterwards, it decides to show you EVERY. SINGLE. EVENT. that's available to you on the map. (This took about a minute and 30 seconds of showing me huge banners on the map that I could see without the forced preschool session.) The tutorial treats you like a 5 year old who accidently got on your brothers console, it's boring, long, embarrassing, aggravating, and degrading. I'd rather watch paint dry. Twice. Then play anymore of this clear cash grab. As I always say, "maybe next year Ubisoft, but probably not." 2/10

Overall fun game. First, the bad:
1. Mind-numbing decision to put gear ratings on your bicycle and equipment. Real-world road bicycles can cost tens of thousands of dollars, but past a certain upper-level point, there's no difference between the $1000 road bike and the $5500 bike... except that the guy riding the $5500 bike is a dentist, while the guy riding the $1000 bike isn't divorced three times
2. Your avatar, a Ageless-Faceless-Gender-Neutral-Culturally-Ambiguous-Adventure-Person, appears to have spent a lot of time eating Big Macs instead of hitting the cranks (not that there's anything wrong with crushing Big Macs... now I want a Big Mac...), and holding down the accelerator after hitting an arbitrary top speed on a flat does nothing
3. Unskippable tutorials. Don't let some weird guy tell me how to ride a bicycle, especially that one in a straw trilby. He looks like he should be getting verbally destroyed on camera by Chris Hansen and subsequently arrested. Seriously, the NPCs are beyond forgettable and could be replaced by text tutorials.

The weird:
1. Crammed with massively cringey Gen Z slang that's already dated. It sounds like it was written by a Baby Boomer that Ubisoft found cryogenically frozen in a vault
2. You can't physically contact other riders, which is good sportsmanship, but annoying to play. If you're encouraging me to jump off the trail and take shortcuts between checkpoints, I should also be allowed to knock another cyclist off his bike at 50 miles an hour and laugh as he slams headfirst into a tree stump
3. There's no discernible reason to win races. Seriously. I can't tell if there's any difference in rewards if you win or come in last place. This is probably good, because if you miss a checkpoint, the rewind feature only rewinds the player, and the NPC racers are unaffected- you will almost absolutely need to reset the race.

The good:
1. Controls are solid, and there are plenty of options for control schematics
2. A lot- seriously, a lot- of accessibility options, which is positive to see
3. ... to be determined. I'll edit this as more positives come up, or refund if none do.

If you got it for $15 when it first released for steam, than you already won,

On a real note -
The game itself is beautiful and can be fun if you dont rage at sudden glitches and things that ruin the racing experience, Example: During a Mass race against 60 other people, you could be in first and suddenly crash into a random invisible barrier, and there goes your #1.

Also, the hoverboard is probably the most agonizing thing I've ever experienced in a game like this. It'll get boring and repetitive after the first 10 hours you put into it unless you enjoy overachieving absolutely everything possible, then you're just in it for pain, you filthy masochist.

Also, you cant really buy a lot in the game with the cash you win from races and stuff, they really just want your real money for stuff that wont make to much of a difference in the long run.

I advise you to have more than 16gb of RAM and a pretty decent Graphics card, I'm running a  NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050, 32g Ram, and it runs like a charm for me.

Amazing and very fun experience once you get the controls customized to your own play-style!
The majority of the game is free to explore with some content for certain events and activities locked behind a paywall.
You level your character by completing contracts, weekly and seasonal objectives, discovering new locations and competing in events.  
As you progress you are rewarded with  new items for your character and upgraded gear. 
The in store market offers cosmetic only skins and unlock-able items, none of which will give you an advantage when it comes to the multiplayer. 
50 players per server with tons of activities to choose from, including Mass Races usually occurring every 15 minutes. 
Recommended if you enjoy any outdoor activities and adrenaline inducing competition!

I've been burnt out from gaming for years, I couldn't play games for more than 10 minutes before getting bored.
Riders Republic changed that forever.
I've played this game today for 13 hours in one session. Let me tell you why:
This game is all about progression, levelling up, and getting better gear.
The fact that, no matter if you get first or last place, you will make progress, regardless of your difficulty setting or gear level.
I had so much fun riding down hills, doing tricks on the snow board, doing impossible 1440s and so on.
There's literally so much you can do, from bikes, paragliding to even funny and weird gear like a pizza bike or a giraffe costume.
It's an amazing experience overall, even with the weird visual glitches.

I WOULD easily give this game a 11/10
But unfortunately, it's far from being a perfect or well thought out game.

Here are my complaints about the game:
Almost everything like clothing, even careers (sport modes) requires real money, and it's not cheap.
I bought the standard edition of this game for 15 euros. After playing for hours and having fun, I decided to get the most of this game, like the bmx career, by buying 2.3k worth of republic tokens (real money currency). The bmx career costs 2k tokens to unlock, that's around 20 bucks. If that's not crazy enough, wait until you see the price of single items and outfit bundles, 900 to 2k tokens, that's around 10-20 euros, it's a ridiculous price! And it needs to be reduced to something reasonable.  
But don't worry there are also items on the shop that can be acquired from in-game earned bucks, but there are 2 two problems: 1. There's not much to see on the shop for bucks. 2. They're also very expensive, keep in mind i've been playing for 13 hours, have almost 500 stars and around 50k bucks, and items cost 20k bucks, seriously???

Thank you for reading my review this far.
In conclusion, this is an awesome game, but unfortunately the prices of items make the standard edition not worth it, so don't make my mistake and buy the 30 euro/dollars edition of this game, unless you don't plan to play this for long.

this just seems like another classic Ubisoft cash grab.
the only pros of the game is the gameplay is fun and the map is really big and it has fun sections. 
but the cons heavily outweigh the pros. the in-game currency you receive by actually playing the game is almost completely worthless. almost all of the accessories and all of the funkies (funny sports equipment) are only purchasable with the in-game currency you have to actually buy with real money. Ubisoft has also locked some of the game away in a $40 season pass. 
I'm so sick of games putting stuff behind paywalls. remember back in the good 'ol days when DLC had an actual fair price and wasn't just skins? well that memory is fading fast. if you want to buy a better version of this game, buy steep, where you can actually use the in-game currency you get from actually playing the game
most AAA game companies have tarnished their legacies. 

Blizzard and Activison have stopped trying to make new IPs for quite awhile

343 has screwed up every game they have made so far, especially infinite when they made the first ever halo game with microtransactions

Yo, dudes and dudettes, hold on to your surfboards 'cause I gotta tell you about this gnarly video game I've been shredding lately called Riders Republic. It's like, the most epic gaming adventure you can have without leaving your bean bag!

Okay, so the game is set in this futuristic California, where all the bros and babes have formed their own rad republics. You get to be this sick rider, cruising around on your neon hoverboard, dodging palm trees and jumping over beach volleyball nets. It's like a wild mix of Tony Hawk and Tron, but on a whole new level, bro!

The story is like, totally righteous. You're part of this super cool crew that's all about bringing the stoke back to the republics. You gotta complete all these gnarly missions to unite the factions and take down the boss dudes who are trying to ruin everyone's good vibes. Talk about a righteous adventure!

The graphics, man, they're straight-up trippy. The sunsets over Malibu are so vivid, they'll make your eyes pop. And the characters, oh boy! You got this dude with a handlebar mustache, all about the retro vibes, and this chick with rainbow hair, spreading love and positivity like a human disco ball. The game designers totally nailed the California vibes, bro!

Now, the controls take a bit of getting used to, like finding your balance on a shaky surfboard. But once you get the hang of it, you'll be pulling off tricks that'll make even the pros jealous. Plus, you can customize your board and gear with all kinds of rad stickers and neon paint jobs. Gotta look fly while saving the republics, right?

But here's the real kicker, my dudes: the soundtrack! It's like they took all the best tunes from the '80s and mixed 'em up with some futuristic beats. Picture this: you're grinding on a rail, doing flips, and jamming out to some sick synthwave. It's like time-traveling to the ultimate beach party, bro!

Overall, Riders Republic is the ultimate game for all you California dreamers out there. It's got the sun, the sand, the sick tricks, and a righteous mission to save the republics. So grab your shades, twist one for ya boy, start up the game, and get ready to ride into a totally tubular gaming adventure that'll leave you stoked for days, dude! 

Cowabunga! 🤙

im just going to keep a list of things that have happened in game:
- at the end of a solo race the podium characters all did the same animation in sync, like a fucking dance troupe
- my character started un-ironically doing the dollar dollar bills hand gesture and i had no choice in this
- there is one long hair preset, it is made of jelly fish
- republic.... coins..... because i didnt just buy a fucking game for the game, so i have to buy the game in bits and pieces after already buying the game
- you earn in game money for completing things... roughly 2 things in customisation menu uses this money. the other few hundred cost those "republic coins." i didnt just buy a game, i brought access to an online NFT market place, NFTs that other people can also buy, so if regular NFTs have no value, this is negative value
- there are no white flat sole sneakers to choose, what the fuck, an actual staple of extreme sports culture and you dont have it as a default option?
- your body clips through the only decent pair of default trousers... note, you dont get to change your body shape, everyone has the same shape, how is this still a thing after a year of beta testing on other stores?
- you cant change your snowboard boots.... thats like basic customisation for snowboarding
- the practice bowl is so busy you cant even see what the fuck you are doing
- i just spent 5 minutes being dragged back and forth around a GPS map,to be shown a bunch of clearly sign posted events that did not need to be pointed out to me individually
- there is a prada event? what, ran out of sponsors for your shit game?
- i just got wedged in a kicker and turned in to a 15 odd foot long monstrosity
- i dont know what a shackdaddy bandit is, nor do i want to know, they seem like a bunch of tools. im guessing theyre meant to be cool, but they come across as try hards sharing a single brain cell
- #lonewolf .... its not even bad at this point, just sad
- the burger granddad is getting annoying, i wish he would stop 
- the gps dragging is getting boring too
- the little ski board is pretty good, maybe the skateboarding when it releases will be fun, but im not holding out hope.

ok, so where should i start.

First the (few) good things:
Its a big and beautiful open world thats fun to play in.
Its cool to play in multiplayer and the community seems pretty chill.
There are lots of sports that you can choose from and you can also pick your own playstyle.

Now to the cons:
After some time, it gets kinda boring.
The game feels a bit soulless compared to steep.
They try to make the characters in the cutszenes feel badass but its just really cringe.
and OH BOY, the microtransactions. Its a full pice game and still they throw in microtransactions. And its not just the cosmetics. To unlock cool stuff like a rocket powered bike you need the year pass. FOR 40$. Thats just a shameless money grab.

Its really got potential, but ubi just destroys it w microtransactions.
its good to have some short term fun, but not much more.
you will be bette off playing steep or descenders.

Basically just Steep but they added bikes (all of the other sports are mostly here, with some mashed together to make room to split race and trick stuff up in the sport menu). They did recognize Steep players by adding options for a Steep-like control scheme and Steep's auto-landing style.

Still massively covered in microtransactions, seemingly all cosmetic at this point, but due to prevalence it makes it difficult to see what stuff is actually purchasable using the standard currency.

Generally it's fun, if you play Steep, you should be able to enjoy it, with a slight learning curve for new trick functions.

Riders republic does a lot of things right;
* massive races (player numbers)
* a lot of different and fun locations and areas
* good graphics, try indulging just free riding without HUD
* a lot of players at almost all parts of the map, you don't feel alone
* this game just scratches my ick of massively multiplayer open world where people could just ride around or just doing tricks, falling over.
* a bunch of different sports and rides to choose from, some behind a paywall (UBISOFT)
* these games just get me in the vibe, i wanna be on a rainy saturday afternoon.
* I WANT MORE OF THESE GAMES!!!

Now, it has good graphics but not much has changed since 2016, when steep came along and now it's not a disrespect cause steep to this day holds itself up so well and is very pretty, but thinking the difference that'll come between 5 years would be a lot but it's not much.
The snow part, there is not even a disscussion that steep handled snow and snow sports so much better than RR, i mean ofc it was just a snow sports focused game but still.
The Biking is a new sport added here and tbf it's a cool addition. I like the fact that this game gives me the option to try out more varied landscapes and sports, like atleast i have the option if i need it.
RR has much more complexities to it, i am all welcome to the various skills and tricks but this game is just very complex and grindy.
The one thing i loved the most in Steep was just freeriding and doing tricks and skills amidst free riding, everything felt so natural, in this game the natural aspect is less felt and kills my immersion sometimes.
I am nowhere saying this is a bad game game, instead it is a very fun game and super bang for your buck at sale.
I have played this game on console and now here, I love this game and man do i adore Steep so much, i want more of these titles and games like these.

Riders republic is an awesome game for pure fun and chaos, and also to escape from chaos to just freeride with HUD off and just feel the calm.
With it feeling more arcade in controls (switching to manual and removing assists helps a lot) and overly grindy, these sure are some negatives.

This is an Awesome game and few of the fun ones that ubisoft has made in the past couple of years.
I recommend it to everyone

TLDR: Save your money, the game is hot garbage.

Coming from Descenders, this game is literally unplayable. Controls are horrible and stiff, I feel like I'm sliding along the ground in a cardboard box, and not riding a mountain bike.

A friend of mine called it "The Crew of extreme sports", but this controls a lot worse than The Crew does compared to sims or even Forza Horizon.

The kicker is that on an RX 6600 8gb the game drops to 40-something FPS every few corners in a race.
